<DIV></DIV>&gt;Date: Mon, 22 Jul 2002 01:52:28 -0400
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Anastasios,
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Dave Marsh has spent his time on earth writing:
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Born to Run: The Bruce Springsteen Story
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Trapped: Michael Jackson and the Crossover Dream
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Before I Get Old: The Story of the Who
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Elvis
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The Book of Rock Lists
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Sun City: The Making of the Record
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Glory Days: Bruce Springsteen in the 1980s
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Louie Louie
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Merry Christmas Baby: Holiday Music from Bing to Sting
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The New Book of Rock Lists
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The Great Rock'n'Roll Joke Book
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Alan Lomax made thousands of recordings of people from all over the
<DIV></DIV>&gt;world
<DIV></DIV>&gt;playing music never intended for the market. I've got a bunch of
<DIV></DIV>&gt;them. You
<DIV></DIV>&gt;can borrow some if you actually believe from Marsh's axe-job that
<DIV></DIV>&gt;they're
<DIV></DIV>&gt;ever going to sell more than a couple hundred or so copies of most
<DIV></DIV>&gt;of them.
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Lomax would have made more money writing about Bruce Springsteen,
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The Who,
<DIV></DIV>&gt;and Michael Jackson. Hell, he would have made more money writing
<DIV></DIV>&gt;about King
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Crimson or Bread. Marsh's notion that Lomax stuck to recording folk
<DIV></DIV>&gt;music
<DIV></DIV>&gt;from around the world because those people didn't become stars and
<DIV></DIV>&gt;that way
<DIV></DIV>&gt;he could remain all-powerful is the most cynical thing I've read in
<DIV></DIV>&gt;a long
<DIV></DIV>&gt;time. The only thing I can think when I read that is Wow: Marsh
<DIV></DIV>&gt;really
<DIV></DIV>&gt;*does* assume his audience is actually that objectionably stupid.
<DIV></DIV>&gt;(He's
<DIV></DIV>&gt;probably right.) He's also obviously jealous. I'm sure he imagined
<DIV></DIV>&gt;as a
<DIV></DIV>&gt;youth he'd one day be as outrageously cool as Elvis was in his day,
<DIV></DIV>&gt;and here
<DIV></DIV>&gt;he is, a 48-year-old man writing about Sting's holiday music.
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The notion that Lomax fed off the people he recorded all over the
<DIV></DIV>&gt;globe is
<DIV></DIV>&gt;simplistic. He was recording this stuff before it was lost by the
<DIV></DIV>&gt;culture
<DIV></DIV>&gt;itself, which is often what happens as a culture begins to "absorb"
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Western
<DIV></DIV>&gt;influences. Don't get me wrong: It's cool Asmahan could sing
<DIV></DIV>&gt;colluratura
<DIV></DIV>&gt;when she wanted to. And I do think the notion of "pure" folk is
<DIV></DIV>&gt;equally
<DIV></DIV>&gt;simplistic. There's no such thing as "pure" in music, even folk
<DIV></DIV>&gt;music -- all
<DIV></DIV>&gt;over the world it's all got elements (including instruments)
<DIV></DIV>&gt;borrowed from
<DIV></DIV>&gt;other cultures. But there is a definite distinction (immediately
<DIV></DIV>&gt;gettable on
<DIV></DIV>&gt;first hearing) between what Lomax was recording and where the musics
<DIV></DIV>&gt;of
<DIV></DIV>&gt;various cultures were heading. A lot of that stuff is listenable now
<DIV></DIV>&gt;because
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Lomax spent his life traveling around making these recordings. The
<DIV></DIV>&gt;cultures
<DIV></DIV>&gt;themselves mostly weren't doing it. That music simply would have
<DIV></DIV>&gt;been
<DIV></DIV>&gt;forgotten.
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Marsh's piece on Alan Lomax is 100% hearsay (music biz gossip) by a
<DIV></DIV>&gt;man who
<DIV></DIV>&gt;has, himself, made a living writing forgettable crap about mostly
<DIV></DIV>&gt;overrated
<DIV></DIV>&gt;white millionaires, usually well after they ceased being relevant
<DIV></DIV>&gt;enough for
<DIV></DIV>&gt;anyone to really care from whom they stole what they sold.

People interested in TextArc (http://textarc.org):

It's (and I'm) at SIGGRAPH '02 today, tomorrow, and through Friday.
Thanks to overly generous support from the  SIGGRAPH Art Show (where I'm
a "working artist"--actually printing and tweaking the work based on
attendee feedback), Roland (who loaned a gorgeous 8 ink 55" printer and
donated supplies), and SMART Tectnologies (who loaned 2 50" plasma
display touch screens).

Come see me if you're near San Antonio!

Here's what the booth looks like late Monday, after the first whole day:
http://textarc.org/appearances/SIGGRAPH02/mondayEvening.jpg

And I've released a new version of TextArc, available under the link
that says "Thousands of Texts" at http://textarc.org. There's a not
complete, nor fully documented major feature (word pairs) that you can
tinker with at the lower left corner of the screen. And a few more
changes--I'll detail them soon at the site.

Thanks for the interest and support!

Brad

Date:         Mon, 22 Jul 2002 21:32:34 -0700

From:         Sheila Murphy <shemurph2001@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Found - collaborative magnetism
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Nick, I appreciate the reference to your exploration
of found poetry of a few years ago. The magnetic field
that is created by this process is one that continues
to fascinate me, largely because of the wealth of
possibilities in attitude, positioning, and so forth.
You cite a very positive and growth-inducing approach,
wherein the collaborative magnetism can be enhanced
through recognition and acknowledgement of the
initiating object.

I'm interested in a proposed neutrality of the
original/initiating object and its perceived
evolutionary passages, and equally in what might
hypothetically become an aggressive act of
repositioning the original. Magnetic fields are
created by actively repositioning the sphere of
notice.

Just another observation: there seems a kind of life
cycle to the use of found elements in writing. Early
on, there seems an abundance of richness. This may be
in part due to the courtship of early discovery.
Later, as surprise comes to be replaced by at least a
sprinkle of expectation, a waning may take place.

This may apply especially to simple "found"
engagements. Adding complexity, inviting layers of
field, may enhance successive episodes.

Sheila Murphy


> A few years ago I spent quite a bit of time focusing
> on poetry that either
> incorporates "found" writing or appears to.
> Eventually I noticed the close
> relationship between this kind of writing and what I
> called "invented
> languages." I was fascinated by Joan Retallack's
> -Errata suite- (Edge
> Books,1993), which apparently incorporated errata
> slips as the ground or
> basis for poetic texts. In my essay "The Aural
> Ellipsis and the Nature of
> Listening In Contemporary Poetry"(in-Close
> Listening- Oxford UP,1998) I
> employ Benjamin's concept of the aura as well as
> Winnicott's ideas about the
> transitional object to try to bring into focus how
> found materials can exist
> and function within the poem in an intermediate
> space between subjective and
> objective experience.  I discuss that "the
> poetically sophisticated use of
> found language by some of the most distinguished
> experimental contemporary
> poets suggests that an important function of
> contemporary poetry is to
> present readers and listeners with the sites and
> materials of the poem so as
> to invite them to coparticipate in its creation. In
> this sense the writing
> of contemporary poetry has a tendency to become a
> more and more
> collaborative process...These texts point the way to
> telling us how poems
> are created and how to listen closely to our
> responses in order to discover
> the experiential sites  of the poem's constituent
> materials....The found
> poem accentuates the physicality of the poem in both
> written and heard
>

Subject:      PN: philosophers on poetry?
In-Reply-To:  <200207230404.g6N44Ztn004123@mail.localweb.com>

Francis Sparshott, U Toronto.

Routledge published a series of books beginning in the early 1990s along
with the Philosophy Department of the University of Warwick (UK) called
"Studies in Philosophy and Literature."  It has a Continentalist bent.
David Wood from that department wrote a book called _Philosophers' Poets_ in
the series.  The University has a "Centre for Research in Philosophy and
Literature" either in or affiliated with the Philosophy department.

Brendan Lorber asked me to forward this to the list for him -- it was being
bounced back when he tried ... --Gary

One easy, gratuitous, reductionist way to mark the passing of Alan Lomax is
to rip him to shreds. He was attacked in the 50's for his leftist politics &
in the 60's for his work on cantometrics -- so this isn't the first time
someone's attempted to make him the victim of their own self-aggrandizing
agenda.

Another, perhaps more valuable response would be to actually listen to the
music & interviews that he recorded over the course of decades of work &
consider how lucky we are that only 90% of the world's music is now dictated
by Sony. Whether you believe "we celebrate the milkman more than the milk",
the world remains pretty lactose intolerant. Lomax went to great lengths in
his effort to combat the racist, classist monoculture.

An even better reaction to his death might be to slip some money to the
musicians themselves.  Despite Marsh's outrageous claims to the contrary,
making sure musicians got the money & the credit due them was & is, central
to Lomax's mission.

Or am I mistaken?

The site for the Association for Cultural Equity says:

The family suggests that contributions be made to:
The Blues Music Foundation for the Willie Moore Fund
c/o Experience Music Project
2901 3rd Ave
Seattle, WA 98121

Once you've done that, put on one of the albums that you'd never have heard
of were it not for the work Lomax did, file away Marsh's screed as just an
addendum to his seminal opus "The Great Rock'n'Roll Joke Book" & then, if
you want, hit www.alan-lomax.com to contextualize it all.

Brendan Lorber
http://users.rcn.com/lungfull

From:         Robert Corbett <rcor@U.WASHINGTON.EDU>
Subject:      Re: language
Comments: To: Millie Niss <men2@columbia.edu>
In-Reply-To:  <CLEPIOBAJGOOEJNEMJLEIEMCDCAA.men2@columbia.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Could someone define what "romanticization" means here?  Inappropriate
appropriation?  I don't see why reading the signs of mental illness is
that different than portraying extreme human experience (death,
childbirth, homelessness) in general.  I am dubious about the claims being
made in the article, but I don't see why mental illness can't be discussed
by those who aren't mentally ill.  And I think this is what the claim that
mental illness shouldn't be "romanticized" boils down, too.  In other
words, it is simply your basic claim against theory,

Sontag's book on "Illness as a Metaphor" was not about "romanticizing"
aids, but the inevitable way in which certain prominent disorders becomes
metaphors for experience of the general population.  People talked about
societies as "schizophrenic" in a loose way because it was compelling
metaphor, not because there could be a point-by-point comparison between
the experience of schizophrenia for an individual and the experience of
society.  This metaphor was also licensed because early theories of
schizophrenia suggested that its origin was social.  Gregory Bateson wrote
of "schizogenetic" societies (and there is data that shows the disorder
varies according to national borders).  RD Laing's work is clearly in this
tradition, as was Felix Guattari's.  So in a certain sense when these
writers glorified schizophrenia as a form of "truth" about society, it was
because schizophrenia was thought to be less hypocritical response to
society than neurosis.  They certainly did not mean to minimize the pain
of invidual sufferers or to glamorize it.  It was their take on society in
general that was dire.

In any case, I don't think that these metaphors are very prevalent.
There is certain datedness to the argument that hallucinations (whether
organic or artificial in origin) reveal some truth about society.  So a
further point about illnesses as a metaphor is that they shift.  Twenty
years ago, we thought we were all schizophrenic.  Today, the prevailing
disease seems to be obsessive-compulsiveness.  A few years ago, it would
have been eating disorders.  The difference is that while schizophrenics
can seem like prophets or seers, these sufferers are clearly victims.
There was a certain optimism to the schizophrenic society argument that is
absent from current ones.

Robert

--
Robert Corbett                  "I will discuss perfidy with scholars as
rcor@u.washington.edu            as if spurning kisses, I will sip
Department of English            the marble marrow of empire. I want sugar
University of Washington         but I shall never wear shame and if you
                                 call that sophistry then what is Love"
                                                - Lisa Robertson

On Sun, 21 Jul 2002, Millie Niss wrote:

> I lived with someone who has schizophrenia for four years.  He did not see
> any mandalas.  Some of his delusions were indeed funny or "interesting" to
> outsiders, but they tormented him and the voices were insulting and ordered
> him around in a way he couldn't resist.  This kind of theoretical
> romanticization of the experience of schizophrenia really gets me.  I have
> too maany memories of trips to the ER late at night, the voices are telling
> him to operate on me with a paring knife to remove "it," accusations that I
> am a lizard person from outer space made in sincere terror that I might eat
> him and lay eggs which will hatch into other lizards which will eat him, his
> head filled with weasels eating him brain so that he can feel his mental
> faculties  decline one by one as the weasels hit that spot, the martian
> commander zarvox giving him orders to do biozarre things that if he reaveals
> to anyone he will be killed.
>
> I remember visiting him after ODs, with the IV bottles running into him,
> after they have fed him the charcoal.  And on suicide watch in the mental
> hospital, where you have to pee and shower with the door open.  I remember
> the endless conversations I would have with social workers and doctors,
> trying to push whatever new treatment or idea I had heard of lately, while
> the people I talked to sort of thought "yet another chronic schizophrenic.
> They never get well."
>
> Literary and philosophical texts which represent schizophrenic experience as
> creative are missing the point.  I have met some creative folk who have the
> illness.  In some cases the illlness is involved in the creativity I think.
> But delusions are not creative and are not pleasant, even if the
> delusioonary content is somewhat pleasant, because one is always faced with
> the contrast between reality oan one's delusion-- there will be lots of
> evidence that the delusion is false and people will get all angry trying to
> convince the sick person to give up the delusion and it is painful to fight
> for one's sense of reality.  It is not creative because delusional content
> (and likewise for hallucinations) is utterly involuntary.  It suposedly
> comes from rather random brain activity which the brain parses into words
> and thoughts because _any_ sequence of firing of neurons has a meaning.  But
> even if the content comes from the unconscious, it is not creative as one
> doesn't create it--it just happens instantly.  And usually delusonal systems
> are full of holes -- contradictions and things which are noit explained by
> them.  Pointing these out does not make the person give up the delusion
> though; they just immediately manufactire more delusion to fill in the gaps.
>
> Millie
>

> I was sent this on another list and I think the approach is more productive

> I'm happy to announce an intersting new article in the PsyArt journal, a
> Jungian
> study of schizophrenia by Leslie Trueman at Rutgers University.  The title
> is:
> The Mandala Experience : Visions of the Center in Schizophrenic and
> Fictional
> Accounts of Disintegration.  And here is its abstract:
>
>               Schizophrenia
>               is commonly viewed as a paradigm of disintegration, but C.G.
> Jung
>               and J. Weir Perry were among those who noticed that
> schizophrenics
>               often have visions of the mandala, a symbol of the center.
> These
>               visions, or &quot;mandala experiences&quot; are in Jung's
> words,
>               &quot;an attempt at self-healing&quot; through &quot;the
> construction
>               of a central point to which everything is related.&quot; Two
> schizophrenic
>               experiences of mandalas are given to illustrate. One
> experience
>               is Jung's who arguably had a breakdown of schizophrenic
> proportions.
>               The other can be found in the life of John Nash, a
> schizophrenic
>               made famous by the recent film biography, &quot;A Beautiful
> Mind.&quot;
>               The presence of such hitherto undetected moments of
> constructiveness
>               during psychic distintegration prompts a reevaluation of
> writers
>               such as Kafka, who are commonly viewed as poets of
> disintegration.
>               His &quot;Description of a Struggle&quot; is a search for, and
> temporary
>               attainment of the healing center amidst such psychic
> disintegration.
>
>

content


(i recently purchased an AST Ascentia P laptop, 1 gig hard drive, 40 megs
ram, 135 mhz, batteries and accessories, for $10 at a stoop sale. the
operating system is Redhat linux 6.2. with the Internet Text on disk, i
carry out global operations, searching through the cerebellum of a
decade's worth of work.)

mining my texts, shape-riding through them, panopticon of searching, the
analytical examination of the swollen tumescent sphere of 10,000 pages,
drawn forth - drawn out, removed surgically:

    4  grep spherical * > /root/zz
    9  grep -h spherical * > /root/zz
   13  grep -h tumescent >> /root/zz
   14  grep -h tumescent * >> /root/zz
   18  h >> zz

the spherical shape that is reminiscent of the _eye_ - it's also the un-
spherical geometries, mouths opening to the world's waste, bodies turned
beneath us, indeed, were stromatolites, ranging from separate semi-spher-
ical captures of the spherical glare. we have image on a spherical
projection. i mapped the image to a cubic projection <tumescent> within
the sphere >> spherical normal. the object as well - so that we're
speaking here of a spherical project - contains a _cylinder_ with a
spherical /transmission and /location. your skins expand into spherical
orbit.

tenuous connections, these ligaments of cyberspace, almost a tumescent
waiting for your clotted tongue, so tumescent bodies fill all space all
corners of tumescent eyes ,, body read, produced, tumescent and
pronounced.

_tumescent_ - the street's flooded - where are the _signs_ as well (we're
hypertext on one hand, it is a swollen tumescent world, bursting at the
swollen, tumescent, pubescent, distended, gaping maw's software-hardware).
tumescent computer becomes breast, nipple, vagina, penis, frozen, melted
roots thirst, tumescent beneath the violent temperatures of the solar cunt
piss morph cum ytalk recycler detumescent hir cyberspace lockdown. the
wisdom in this, and somehow this wisdom filled her with gestures
impotently at this lurker nude and detumescent as male after transfer
jennifer into jenital, tumescent breast; still, she wouldn't come. i
transfer maya into jenital, tumescent breast; still, she won't come. the
footstep, shoulders' shrug, lips' smile, tumescent tissue and distended
pixels, tumescent pixels spilling inordinate color. Oh, a mixup!

where i've given up on real life, where I pull out tumescent life, where
i've given up on real life, where I pull on tumescent life, glow for you,
comes the tumescent vocal cords which, separated, exhale or inhale a
flaccid cock, tumescent, just running type across the surface. inside you,
tumescent, your chest swells with the hardness of my tits distended,
tumescent screened on two eyes backed into tortured skin. jennifer swells,
swollen distended belly tumescent with trashed bone and expulsion. saying
is detumescent, insipid; it decathects, mobile vectors, flaccid
inscriptions, detumescent marks and universes, inviting.

i can cry and see so very hard. My body is not tumescent. i do not.
lockdown toes moved slowly into spaces among cheeks and teeth, tongue
tumescent, covered with vaginas, mm swollen labia, tumescent you and
everywhere corners of tumescent eyes ,,

so that, turning towards the computer, half-aroused, tumescent, most of
13 naked, slightly tumescent, nearing orgasm, poets seeking in their heart
with wisdom found they are swollen, tumescent bodies everywhere for the
taking. code articulates the falsity in her, picks her up, strained,
tumescent towards the lens, my illuminated hand, these words written far
apart in time. capital flourishing from the beautiful energies,
tumescent, through the writing or against fingers hovering above the
tumescent keyboard, sense of iridescent _frisson,_ <tumescent> within
sphere >> spherical normal, above

It is interesting that when war comes the avant-garde breaks down, as if the
emergency of the moment is too real to hold pure experimentations together.
So, I suggest, like in physics, what is needed is an experimental language
that proves itself in a larger than academic world. In either case, your
review focused some issues. Thank you!

Best,
Joel

Date:         Tue, 23 Jul 2002 18:43:43 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Gary Sullivan <gpsullivan@HOTMAIL.COM>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

Hi Anastasios,

I'm all for balance, especially w/respect to the venerated. So, okay.

This will take some time, but let's see what Marsh actually has to offer:

In the first paragraph containing factual (anecdotal) evidence, Marsh
writes: "In 1993, when Lomax published The Land Where the Blues Began, his
memoir of blues research in the deep South, Peter Bochan invited him to do a
WBAI interview. Bochan ventured to Lomax that Elvis Presley stood as a great
product of the Southern folk cultures. Lomax firmly denied this, and said
that Bochan couldn't even know that Presley had listened as a boy to Sister
Rosetta Tharpe's gospel radio show because "You weren't there." He said this
so persistently and adamantly -- with all the stupid "folklorist" purism
that ruined the folk music revival--that Bochan went home and intercut
Lomax's prissy voice and dumb assertions with excerpts from Beavis and
Butthead. It aired that way."

Forgetting for a moment slanted phrases like "stupid 'folklorist' purism"
"prissy voice" and "dumb assertions" (this is "balanced" journalism?) --
what is Marsh's source for this?

He doesn't say. We assume then, it's that recording, with the Beavis and
Butthead excerpts. Either that, or Bochan himself.

In other words, Marsh's only evidence for this "fact" about Lomax is a sound
recording made by an interviewer who has grotesquely manipulated it and then
broadcast it with the sole intention of making a man he's just had an
argument with look bad.

This is evidence only that Bochan is an unethical broadcaster. Even if Marsh
got the story from Bochan himself, who would trust a guy who'd do that? My
sense, reading the above anecdote, is that the two clashed, as people
sometimes do, and that Bochan used what power he had as a radio person to
make Lomax look bad. It doesn't say much for Bochan's character.

The next paragraph: "As a veteran blues observer wrote me, "Don't get too
caught up in grieving for Alan Lomax. For every fine musical contribution
that he made, there was an evil venal manipulation of copyright, publishing
and ownership of the collected material."

"A veteran blues observer." What does that mean? No name is mentioned.
Worse, note that there is not a single factual event even mentioned in said
"veteran's" condemnation. Yet Marsh feels justified trotting this out as
evidence.

The next paragraph is where Marsh supposedly delivers the goods:

Marsh: "The most notorious concerns "Goodnight Irene." Lomax and his father
recorded Huddie "Leadbelly" Ledbetter's song first, so when the song needed
to be formally copyrighted because the Weavers were about to have a huge hit
with it, representatives of the Ledbetter family approached him. Lomax
agreed that this copyright should be established. He adamantly refused to
take his name off the song, or to surrender income from it, even though
Leadbelly's family was impoverished in the wake of his death two years
earlier."

There's a serious problem with the above paragraph.

Alan Lomax's name is *not* on the copyright.

It's Alan's father, John Lomax.

Here's another version of the story: In "The Life and Legend of Leadbelly",
authors Charles Wolfe and Kip Lornell claim that Leadbelly didn't really
write a song that got him a pardon from prison as was legend, and that
"Goodnight Irene" is based on a Gussie Davis song from 1892. When John Lomax
toured Leadbelly (Alan was simply working for his father), a NY promoter
worried about Leadbelly's time in prison ... and decided instead of hiding
it to make the most of it -- he got Leadbelly and John Lomax to agree to
have Leadbelly dress in prison clothes, to help puff up the myth.

John Lomax. Not Alan Lomax.

So, what Marsh here has done is (a) substitute Alan's father for Alan and
(b) tell only a fraction of the story -- if, indeed, the fraction he's
telling has any legitimacy whatsoever. He cites it as "notorious." I'm
assuming that means it's been documented somewhere, as Marsh has described
it? What I've quoted above may not be accurate either. But at least I'm
documenting a published account. It's more than Marsh has done here.

Marsh again: "Lomax believed folk culture needed guidance from superior
beings like himself."

No documentation whatsoever to support this.

Marsh: "Lomax told Bochan what he believed: nothing in poor people's culture
truly happened unless someone like him documented it."

Lomax said this? Where? On that tape? The one Bochan manipulated with Beavis
and Butthead excerpts? I don't believe Lomax ever made such a statement.

More Marsh: "He hated rock'n'roll--down to instigating the assault against
Bob Dylan's sound system at Newport in '65--because it had no need of
mediation by experts like himself."

Aldon reported something similar -- I guess this is on film, and I'm not
going to dispute it, although I've never personally seen it. One point for
Marsh. Hardly evidence of Lomax as "fraud," "thief" or "plagiarist" -- the
primary charges Marsh makes -- the reason, supposedly, we're reading his
essay.

Marsh: "The nature of the expert mattered, too. Lomax's obit made the front
page mainly because he "discovered" Son House and Muddy Waters."

A guy who "discovers" two singers isn't going to make the cover of the
Times, otherwise there'd be a guy or gal like that on the cover every couple
months or so. Lomax is there because he did many interesting things with his
life -- some of which had profound repercussions in this and other cultures.
I'd say he's there because of a general paradigm shift -- people in the U.S.
becoming (at least somewhat) more aware of multiculturalist takes on
culture. (And I think that's partially what "irks" (read: frightens) Marsh,
actually -- but, that's just a belief on my part.)

Marsh again: "But in Can't Be Satisfied, his new Muddy Waters biography,
Robert Gordon shows that Lomax's discoveries weren't the serendipitous
events the great white hunter portrayed."

Lomax portrayed these discoveries as serendipitous events ... where? Marsh
doesn't say. Again, no evidence is offered. Neither is any evidence offered
for Gordon's having "showed us" this. It's just stated.

Marsh: "Lomax was led to House and then Waters by the great Negro scholar,
John Work III of Fisk University. Gordon even shows Lomax plagiarizing Work,
and not on a minor point. (See page 51)"

There's no evidence in either of those two sentences above to support the
claims made. John Work III was an academic enthomusicologist and a composer.
He may very well have led Lomax to both blues men. I'm assuming that people
led Lomax to everyone Lomax recorded, and that he didn't just parachute down
randomly with a 500-pound recording device. How else would he find all of
these people?

The second assertion, about plagiarizing Work, "not on a minor point," is
unsubstantiated. There's a page number to look up. (If someone finds this,
please post it.) We can't evaluate it in the article itself -- it's
(conveniently?) missing.

Marsh again: "In his book, Lomax offers precisely one sentence about Work.
He eliminated Work from his second Mississippi trip."

Work is the guy everyone was expected to go through to meet all of the blues
singers in the south? This is just weird. Lomax is expected to publish in
his book long descriptions of all of the hundreds, possibly thousands, of
people who lead him to people playing folk and indigenous music? That's like
asking Marsh to publish long descriptions of all of the djs and radio
stations where he first heard the 1000 rock and soul songs he wrote his book
about. It doesn't make sense.

Marsh: "He also burned Muddy Waters for the $20 he promised for making the
records."

What's the source for this? Again, like most of the above, it's just stated
without evidence.

And that's it. Those are all of the purported "facts" in Marsh's essay I was
able to dig out.

The rest of it is just slanted words and phrases like "thief," "bigot,"
"hunter," "Harry Smith syndrome" (!!), "prissy," "stupid," and on and on, a
stream of vitriol, none of it substantiated in any way whatsoever.

I don't hate Marsh. But this isn't my idea of an honest attempt to "balance"
the hagiography. That would require someone with some factual information
sharing it. Preferably without a bunch of name-calling in every paragraph.

As of this writing, the counterpunch.org site's link to Marsh's essay says:
"Mr. Big Stuff: Alan Lomax, Great White Fraud."

I've tried writing this without letting anger get the best of me. Let me
know, Anastasios, if I'm being unfair in pointing out that Marsh's piece is
not only vicious, but in all likelihood untrue.

In a roundabout way I think the review highlights a crucial cultural
watershed and the importance of Khlebnikov's process or 'with' response to
the hAZArds of life.  Your response here, Joel, led me to thinking about a
contemporary process approach at the time by Trotsky whonot only got
swallowed by what he helped set in motion was also and perhaps more
significantly anti-experimentalism as not utilitarian.  Perhaps then as now
it is the resistance to experimentation or process that culminates in
either/or, us/them ways of seeing and thinking that have no tolerance for
poetic p[rocess?

tom bell

talking, i mean what they say to you this is the sign of the waters black
with ripples, the glimpse of moon's sphere, trembling, sounds of the
humans would have read this long ago. the pages, yours, letters swollen,
loving your mouth. the grist of letters among protrusions of the text
split, splayed for modification, this is the map or when emissions, spews
replace chaos by noise, substance, binding of names a shrieking angel
earth lapping at the mournful sprits *me me me // ashes *gathering place
& mournful sprits *me me me

recent discussions here and on another list have prompted me to offer a workhop on putting it together agian experimentally:

Tell iT sLANT




Week 1. Readings and discussion. Yes, you have to read something! I will provide a list of 5 or 6 readings and each participant is asked to suggest a book or article.

Week 2. Report to the group the method you have selected for 'slanting' your writing.

Week 3. Provide a sample of your work in progress. Submit and accept criticism. If participants have had trouble getting started, there will be an [WARNING!] EXERCISE.

Week 4. Discussion of problems getting started, thoughts on relation of the process to theoretical readings from week 1, and any problems with group cohesion, atmosphere, support, etc.

Week 5. Second work sample or [WARNING!] EXERCISE/

Week 6. Conclusion and exchange of thoughts on where to submit your work for consideration.

-----

cost will be $60.  This is not a fancy telecourse thing, just email exchange, but you do get group support.  course will start when I hear from 8 people.



tom bell

My initial ref. was not so much to the Dylan sound system episode, about which there is much dispute, as to the Lomax/Grossman wrestling match, which has been well documented from all sides -- I also ref'd Lomax's uncomprehening response to Dylan's performance at Newport, stands whether or not you choose to believe that Lomax went nuts at the performance itself.

CAN'T BE SATISFIED, by Robert Gordon, narrates the Lomax/Work/Waters encounters in chapter 3, and includes a photo of one of the four letters Waters dictated and mailed to Lmax seeking the promised payment and "contributor's copy"  (sound familiar, poets?) - - I think the record makes it clear that Gordon is correct when he argues that "Lomax virtually erased the scholarship of John Work" (51) -- People familiar with the histories of African American music and of AFrican AMerican scholars have known these stories for decades --

We need neither hagiographies nor trashings -- we do need to recognize that the same Lomax who ripped people off also opened doors and brought wider attention to deserving musicians -- I think it was that bittersweet sort of realization that motivated Dylan's stage acknowledgement of Lomax that one day in Virginia --

Lomax did much good & much wrong -- we need to understand all of it together --

In-Reply-To:  <Pine.A41.4.44.0207220955490.91878-100000@dante14.u.washington.edu>

>At 10:57 AM -0700 7/23/02, Robert Corbett wrote:
>Sontag's book on "Illness as a Metaphor" was not about "romanticizing"
>aids, but the inevitable way in which certain prominent disorders becomes
>metaphors for experience of the general population . . .


I like a lot of what Corbett is saying in his post "language" but I
think his simple typo will confuse some of those who aren't familiar
with Susan Sontag's writing . . .  It's just a slip of the pen
(keyboard) in which he conflates Sontag's 1979 book ILLNESS AS
METAPHOR with her much later book on AIDS (AIDS AND ITS METAPHORS)--

Obviously the "Illness as Metaphor" book came too early to deal with
AIDS.  It was a groundbreaking book in its day due to its startling
thesis--that disease is not a metaphor, nor a punishment, that it's
just something that happens to the  body, and that despite the
overwhelming urge to use illness as a description of something else
(often a zeitgeist--Sontag shows that TB, or consumption, was popular
earlier in the 20th century as a convenient descriptive, allusive
shorthand for current problems--think of "The Magic Mountain"--while
by century's end cancer had become the "disease of choice" among
litterateurs anxious to describe the social, moral, political
conditions in which they found themselves.)

"AIDS and Its Metaphors" is a markedly inferior book of little value,
you get the idea she was just re-treading everything she had said in
the first book, except eerily enough she sometimes winds up
suggesting that AIDS is a different order of disease than, say,
cancer and yes, indeed, it may therefore be used as a metaphor,
and/or may with propriety breed the sorts of metaphors attached to
it, which she had so firmly ruled out earlier.  However from what I
understand she donated all the money she made from this book to AIDS
relief and activist efforts, so that's as they say all good.
Otherwise a horrid disappointment and a time waster par excellence.

-- Kevin K. 2002


>People talked about
>societies as "schizophrenic" in a loose way because it was compelling
>metaphor, not because there could be a point-by-point comparison between
>the experience of schizophrenia for an individual and the experience of
>society.  This metaphor was also licensed because early theories of
>schizophrenia suggested that its origin was social.  Gregory Bateson wrote
>of "schizogenetic" societies (and there is data that shows the disorder
>varies according to national borders).  RD Laing's work is clearly in this
>tradition, as was Felix Guattari's.  So in a certain sense when these
>writers glorified schizophrenia as a form of "truth" about society, it was
>because schizophrenia was thought to be less hypocritical response to
>society than neurosis.  They certainly did not mean to minimize the pain
>of invidual sufferers or to glamorize it.  It was their take on society in
>general that was dire.
>
>In any case, I don't think that these metaphors are very prevalent.
>There is certain datedness to the argument that hallucinations (whether
>organic or artificial in origin) reveal some truth about society.  So a
>further point about illnesses as a metaphor is that they shift.  Twenty
>years ago, we thought we were all schizophrenic.  Today, the prevailing
>disease seems to be obsessive-compulsiveness.  A few years ago, it would
>have been eating disorders.  The difference is that while schizophrenics
>can seem like prophets or seers, these sufferers are clearly victims.
>There was a certain optimism to the schizophrenic society argument that is
>absent from current ones.
>
>Robert

From:         paula speck <p_speck@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: language
Comments: To: men2@columbia.edu
Mime-Version: 1.0

Millie--

I've published about a dozen personal essays/memoirs drawing on my own life
and incidentally on the lives of people I knew.  I have friends working on
the same kind of thing who've run up against the question you have.  Also,
I'm a lawyer and I've done some First Amendment work.  So here's my
perspective.

Try changing non-essential details (and using a different first name for the
boyfriend, natch) so that the boyfriend isn't easily identifiable.  You
should do this because it's the right thing to do, but it's also the legally
safer thing to do.  Of course, you need to keep the essential details (an
artistic judgment, in the end) so that your writing has grit and truth.

Even if your portrait of someone is favorable in your eyes and in most
readers' eyes, the someone could still be offended.  The other side of this
is that some seemingly unfavorable portraits don't bother the subject at
all--I read somewhere that the mother in *The Liar's Club,* a very raw
family memoir published a few years ago (blanking on the author's name)
loved the book (even though it shows her ignoring sexual molestation of her
daughter, going crazy and piling the family furniture in a bonfire, etc.)
So you never know how the people you write about will react.

The best discussion of this ethical dilemma I've read is in Philip Gerard's
*Creative Nonfiction,* especially pages 150-53, "The Confidence of Family
and Friends" and nearby pages.  He suggests that you show each piece to the
people you're writing about.  The dangers are obvious, including their
making unreasonable objections and your making things worse if you publish
over their objections.  But they could also make suggestions that strengthen
the piece.  It's a tough call, and you say you don't know how to contact the
boyfriend, so it may be impossible anyway.

Speaking as a lawyer, I can only point out that anybody can sue anyone
anytime over anything.  For a libel suit to succeed, the subject has to be
identifiable (that's why I suggest changing details), the statements have to
be disparaging and untrue, etc.  Your boyfriend isn't a public figure (I
assume); there are special rules making it harder for them to sue.  But
there are also new and creative bases for suit, like invasion of privacy and
placement in a disparaging light, etc., etc.  Inertia is your best
protection:  it's unlikely your boyfriend would see the piece, it's unlikely
he'd be upset enough and have the energy to sue, a lawyer wouldn't see you
as a rich enough defendant to be worth suing on contingency, etc.

If it were me, I'd go ahead and revise the piece for publication and send it
out.  If you need to tell this story and can tell it with force and style,
people will want to read it and it will be worth any risks there are.  Good
luck!

Paula Speck

Subject:      nyt article on merce cunningham

------------------------------------------
Celebrating the Vision of Merce Cunningham

July 24, 2002
By JENNIFER DUNNING






Merce Cunningham can no longer move as easily as he once
did. At 83, stricken worse than most with the dancer's
curse of arthritis, he has trouble walking. Adjusting to
this setback, he has revisited a dance form he knew as a
child. "In airports, I have to be pushed around in a
wheelchair because it's 10 miles to anywhere, so you have
to sit around a lot," Mr. Cunningham said. "So I've
realized I could go back to tap-dancing in a wheelchair.
It's marvelous! I've relearned the waltz clog. I'm not too
good yet on the time step."

For all his reputation as a master producer of impenetrably
difficult modern dance, Mr. Cunningham's long voyage
through the art of dance has been surprisingly simple. At
heart, this journey of six decades has been a matter of
"how adroitly you get one foot to the next," as he
describes his notion of rhythm. "Something starts you
thinking about other possibilities," Mr. Cunningham said in
a recent interview at his West Village studio. "Because
there always are. There always are."

That is what has kept him going. "I like dancing," he said
softly. "It's very simple. Probably to most people it's
absurd. But I really think dancing is wonderful. I can't do
it. But I still enjoy the possibility of finding ways,
finding out something else about it."

A private man whom everyone calls Merce, Mr. Cunningham
collaborated with the composer John Cage, who died in 1992,
on work that has expanded the ways artists and audiences
think about dance and even movement itself. Like George
Balanchine, Mr. Cunningham has made it hard to rely
comfortably on the precepts of the past or to shy away from
the advances of the future.

The step-to-step progress of his life's work will be hinted
at this week in the Lincoln Center Festival's 50 Years of
Forward Motion, a two-program retrospective that celebrates
the Cunningham company's 50th anniversary, opening tonight
and closing on Saturday night at the New York State
Theater. The engagement begins a year of 50th-anniversary
projects worldwide that include a free performance on Sept.
3 at Battery Park City and the publication of "Other
Animals," a book of several decades of animal and plant
sketches by Mr. Cunningham.

His response to relative immobility is a perfect example of
how throughout his career Mr. Cunningham has used whatever
was at hand to move into new territory, even
computer-assisted choreography, though he readily admits he
is confounded by the simplest technology. He can no longer
wade into the crowd in rehearsals to demonstrate new
passages of choreography, but that has not stopped him from
creating new dances. And while he was overseeing the
reconstruction of revivals for the festival repertory -
which is to include a premiere, "Loose Time," that explores
rhythm - Mr. Cunningham was at work on a premiere for a
London season in September. He has continued his dancer's
lifelong routine of giving himself a daily private warm-up
at the ballet barre, moving just his feet. He accompanies
his students at the barre in the classes that he teaches
several times a week. "Just so I will do something," he
explained. His attentiveness has been reciprocated. It was
Robert Swinston, a longtime Cunningham dancer and recoverer
of lost Cunningham works, who talked him into reading the
text onstage in the festival revival of "How to Pass, Kick,
Fall and Run." Another dancer, Jeannie Steele, has been
helping Mr. Cunningham with his tap.

"Jeannie's grandma was in the Rockettes, so she knows the
time step, and she shows me every once in a while," he
said. "But somehow I don't connect it. I knew it from Mrs.
Barrett. But the waltz clog I got back."

Maude Barrett was the first dance teacher of Mercier Philip
Cunningham, who began studying tap with her in his early
teens in Centralia, Wash., the small town where he was
born. He was fascinated by vaudeville performances that his
parents took him to, and his fate was sealed by a recital
performance by Mrs. Barrett, dressed in yellow, swinging
juggling clubs and then walking on her hands while talking
to the audience. The stage, he knew, was where he wanted to
be. At home he played jazz piano. In grange halls and
auditoriums he cut a dapper figure performing in ballroom
and tap routines at town events with Mrs. Barrett's
daughter, Marjorie.

Formal theater and dance studies followed at the Cornish
School of Fine Arts in Seattle, where he met Cage, who was
playing piano for classes and teaching at that school and
who was to become Mr. Cunningham's professional and
personal life partner. The young Mr. Cunningham and "three
ladies from the music department" also performed in Cage's
percussion ensemble, Mr. Cunningham recalled, nervously
attacking scores by modernists like Henry Cowell and Lou
Harrison.

"After one rehearsal, John said to one of the music
teachers, `You're playing everything just absolutely
perfect,' " Mr. Cunningham recalled, laughing. " `Now go a
little further and make a few mistakes.' He was very
meticulous about your doing it right. But then you go
forward."

Mr. Cunningham went on to study dance one summer at Mills
College in Oakland, Calif., where a member of the Martha
Graham company noticed the blend of lyrical buoyancy,
sensuality and clarity of shape and rhythm that even then
defined Mr. Cunningham as a dancer and urged Graham to grab
him for her troupe. Mr. Cunningham quickly made a name for
himself as a Graham dancer. Cage, who had also come East,
encouraged him to move away from Graham to create his own
dances.

He presented his first program in 1944 at the
Humphrey-Weidman Studio Theater on West 16th Street in
Manhattan. Less than a decade later, in 1953, the offer of
a summer residence at Black Mountain College in North
Carolina led to the formation of Mr. Cunningham's company.
A core of dancers that he had been working with came with
him to that now-famous incubator of avant-garde arts, among
them a stripling named Paul Taylor and Carolyn Brown, who
is now celebrated as the definitive Cunningham dancer.

It would take another decade for the dancers, who
crisscrossed the United States in a Volkswagen bus, to be
paid at least meager professional wages. That came about
because of the company's triumphant first European tour, in
1964. The tour would have confirmed his belief in the value
of his work, if he had needed confirmation. "See, we had
played here, but very little," he said, referring to
performances in the United States. "And then we went abroad
and played to so many different publics. All of them did
not necessarily like it, by any means, but all of them gave
us the sense that they were interested in what they saw and
what they heard, in some way or another. So we didn't have
to think that we always had to put up a battle."

Winning the acceptance - or at least the interest - of
American audiences has not become much easier over the
years, despite Mr. Cunningham's fame. One difficulty has
been his use of abstruse-seeming chance procedures as a
central creative device, which gave his work the randomness
of a throw of the dice. "Suite for Five," a Cunningham
classic from the 1950's that is to be performed this week,
was choreographed this way.

"Suite for Five" is one of his most beautiful works, a
complex, fluid distillation of time and space. It is also
considered one of his most accessible pieces. Its score, by
Cage, is not typical of the noisy music that used to send
Mr. Cunningham's audiences racing for the exits. And there
are a few recognizable ballet steps and poses to cling to.

Asked about those traces of ballet, Mr. Cunningham
laughed. "If someone puts her leg back behind her and it's
straight, they say it's an arabesque," he said wryly. "I
don't object, because of course it is. My idea always has
been that I want to use as much movement as I can make
possible."

Chance compositional methods can range from consulting the
ancient Chinese book of divination, the I Ching, to
determining elements of a dance by tracing the
imperfections of a piece of paper. "Cunningham uses chance
much as he might use a magnet, to draw possibilities to him
from beyond his reach, and to arrange his materials, like
iron filings, into relationships he might not otherwise
have seen," James Klosty, an early chronicler of the
Cunningham company, wrote in his 1975 book, "Merce
Cunningham." The completed choreography is set, preserved
through performance, notes and video. It was Mr.
Cunningham's vision, Mr. Klosty wrote, to reconcile
precision and the unpredictable.

Ordinary mortals tend to have problems understanding ideas
like this. It is not much easier to grasp the concept of
giving independence to collaborating composers and
designers, whose contributions tend to be introduced at the
first performance.

Mr. Cunningham has an answer for those who worry about
misunderstanding: dance gives one nothing concrete in
return, to paraphrase one of his most famous comments, only
the pleasure of doing and seeing it. His dances are like
small and large worlds whose mysterious daily events unfold
in real time on the stage, with the viewer welcome to enter
and explore without a map. But that kind of freedom can
also be unnerving.

"I don't have any idea how this kind of audience will look
at, say, `Suite for Five,' " Mr. Cunningham said of the
festival pieces. "But they can look at them for what they
are, because the dances are made without intention, that
is, without saying this is about this. We present them, and
present them as well as we can. But we don't try to give
people any idea how they might feel about it. So of course
many people get lost, or say they don't understand, or
whatever. I feel they're missing a kind of experience that
isn't all about dancing by any means."

One of his favorite memories is of an early
lecture-demonstration that he, Cage and the company
presented at a Midwestern concert. "There was one man in
the audience who asked very interesting questions, but in
an irritated manner," Mr. Cunningham recalled. "And John
answered, as he always does, and he was extraordinary.
Finally, this man sighed and said: `Well, I'm so glad they
brought you. Ordinarily, they bring us things like piano
concerts and all we are is entertained.' "

http://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/24/arts/dance/24MERC.html?ex=1028521151&ei=1&
en=a03d95e51fbf690e

I like Yunte's review muchly, but I hardly see how it or the books under
review support the claim that the avante-garde breaks down at the time of
war.  I would also question uncritically reiterating that the current
events constitute a "war" for the US.  Doing so helps legitimate the
actions against civil liberties and shifts in spending priorities--as well
as gives Bush II the drama he was craving (the better to distract you, my
dear)..  And I don't know what is supposed to be meant by "in physics"?
_What_ in physics?  The grand unified theory?  Strings?  I am not psychic
enough to know what is intended.  Finally, if the preeminent modality of
the avante-garde, from Stein to Silliman in Perloff's argument, is
disjunction, then I can easily any number of pop culture documents that
begged, borrowed and stolen these methods.  LP and NYS are simply more
rarefied and elegant versions of what is the contemporary tongue, at least
outside family newspapers, newsweeklies, Hollywood film, and network TV.
And the academy is pretty resistant to disjunction:  it took Williams
forever to get into the canon, Stein even longer, and Djuna Barnes got
there maybe five years ago.

Oof.  I really appreciate the review and the link to it.

Robert

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      essay
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

essay
on
sex.


everything turns to liquid; everything flows, cauterizes. the corrosive
effect on the lip. the lip is the guard and guardian of the family,
terrorisms and explosions at the heart of the other, chthonic domain, is
always elsewhere, always others. we are blind beneath the surface; we
carry atmosphere with us, refusing union. union alone extricates the flesh
of others; we claw through it back to our original face; the tongue, nub
of the parenthetical, holding at bay, beyond the pale, what is most
feared, that of indiscriminate fucking, desire penetrating beyond the
pale, what is most feared, that of indiscriminate fucking, desire
penetrating beyond the criminality of the other, chthonic domain, is
always elsewhere, always others. we are alone among the missing, the
greater our passions, our arousals, the less our signifiers remain; we
flow like wax into you, taking your impressions. it's politics. it
transforms into the fantasm of an originary state. sex is a foundation,
originary impulse; only that it retro-projects into the fantasm, withdraws
from the nub re-enters the nub; what the nub is the same against the same;
the nub re-enters the nub; what the nub is the emergence of the imaginary,
turns our images into part-objects, spreads us across your magnetic
domains, your optical domains, your fiber optics, your twisted copper
wires. nothing touches anything; the drives are sealed, abjection without.
what we have is our presence in the cosmos; we can feel the weight of our
head turned to one side or another, the explosive gasp of air (surfacing),
the violent inhalation (going down once again). we are always among the
missing. the greater our passions, our arousals, the less our signifiers
remain; we flow like wax into you, taking your impressions. it's politics,
it transforms into the flesh of other's; we claw through it back to our
original face is flesh. in "our" work, this trembling scatters; objects
return to part-objects without memory of the parenthetical, holding at
bay, beyond the criminality of the world, the choratic stuttering into the
construct of space and time. eventually it doesn't need anything at all,
neither body nor viewer, writer nor reader. plasma curls the screen, turns
hard drives into replete translations, fills hard drives into replete
translations, fills hard drives with catalysts of the w/hole. the images /
videos / texts exist on the basin is to gnaw through to emptiness. within
the aegis of gravity, gravitas, it can flood through all pronouncement. it
draws you in. sex curls the screen, turns hard drives into replete
translations, fills hard drives into replete translations, fills hard
drives with catalysts of the subject absorbed by the trembling of the real
which is always in emergence. in "our" work is as explicit as possible. it
is not the reduction of 0*S nor the semiotic; it is all of the nub. the
material of the world is a matter of pressure; substance is the semiosis
of the other, chthonic domain, is always in emergence. in "our" work, we
work the original face. we play against technology, memory, direct and
indirect addressing. we participate in the skein. that which loosens the
grip.


_

been published widely.  Dedicated to Srebrenica, the

massacred in 1995, Ammiel Alcalay's new book, from the
warring factions, is a daring blend of lyric and
document that remaps the world we inherit, from native
New England to the Roman Empire, from the Gulf War to
Palestine and the Balkans.  His translations from the
Middle East, Keys to the Garden , and Bosnia, For/Za

ODD ONES / VENUS STRAPAZZATA DAI LUNATICI, & envoi,

FOR HALVARD JOHNSON

Wait, don't wait for confirmation
while all the oceans of abundance fill
with overabundance-- giving us to woe--
drowning us in want without understanding.

Nothing redeems all our chernobyls
as we are immersed in razorkeen words.
Immediate pain of our Worst Fears Confirmed
leaves an afterburn of revelation as sanity,
as engulfed galaxies seduce that endless
farty leak of darkness and finite light.

Yet, with trophy-wives in one hand --
and catastrophes in the other -- our fear
is where life gathers in preparations
as we move to where all others dream.

Gerald Schwartz
schwartzgk@msn.com

> I was waiting for someone to ask this question.  The answer, of course, is

> political "line," something I think informs third world  experimental
writing
> moreso than U.S. counterpart.

Bill:

There's somewhat of a cultural quandary here, as most Americans, certainly
its educated, if not over-educated, poets, grow up in a privileged space.
Your home is probably not in jeopardy of suddenly being hit by a (American
made) missile, and you're not concerned that when you go shopping someone
will blow you up. Most poets in the Third World don't have the luxury to
experiment like Western poets do. Unlike most Western poets, many Third
World poets speak not so much for themselves as for the sufferings and
aspirations of their people. Their poems, then, are more generous than the
usual first person conceits we find in much Western poetry today. (In some
cases, the first person implies something larger, but I'm not talking to
that.) On the other hand, all worthwhile poems are experimental. It's just
that some are more constrained than others.

-Joel

Joel Weishaus
Center for Excellence in Writing
Portland State University
Portland, Oregon
http://web.pdx.edu/~pdx00282

Date:         Wed, 24 Jul 2002 09:39:05 -1000

From:         "Susan M. Schultz" <schultz@HAWAII.RR.COM>
Subject:      Re: language
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The question of writing about family is one that I've dealt with for several
years now, since I began a project that was recently published as _Memory
Cards & Adoption Papers_ by Potes & Poets.  The first section of this book
is about my mother, who is still very much alive; not all of the material is
complimentary of her, although some of it is quite sympathetic, and I
sometimes wonder if I should have waited longer to publish this material.

The reason I did publish is that the material is not _strictly_ personal.
This is not confession for its own sake, but an attempt, in the first
section of the book, to locate my mother in a historical context (at a
recent reading, I said I wrote about her as "a historical figure" and
someone rightly laughed, but it's true).  The second section of the book
talks about the adoption of my son in the historical context of the Vietnam
war and the "incursion" into Cambodia by Kissinger, et al.  If personal
material is crucial to a thinking through of larger, community, issues, then
I do not find it as much as problem as it might be (as in the school of
"gee, my friend has cancer; here's a chance to write a poem").

If Millie is writing about her friend as a way to get others to think about
mental illness, I say do it.  Of course, Harper's gets wide circulation.  As
poet, I have the benefit of not being read by those who might take
offense...

So, yes, it's a real problem.  Which makes IT worth writing about.

Susan




----- Original Message -----
From: "paula speck" <p_speck@HOTMAIL.COM>
To: <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sent: Wednesday, July 24, 2002 4:13 AM
Subject: Re: language


> Millie--
>
> I've published about a dozen personal essays/memoirs drawing on my own
life
> and incidentally on the lives of people I knew.  I have friends working on
> the same kind of thing who've run up against the question you have.  Also,
> I'm a lawyer and I've done some First Amendment work.  So here's my
> perspective.
>
> Try changing non-essential details (and using a different first name for
the
> boyfriend, natch) so that the boyfriend isn't easily identifiable.  You
> should do this because it's the right thing to do, but it's also the
legally
> safer thing to do.  Of course, you need to keep the essential details (an
> artistic judgment, in the end) so that your writing has grit and truth.
>
> Even if your portrait of someone is favorable in your eyes and in most
> readers' eyes, the someone could still be offended.  The other side of
this
> is that some seemingly unfavorable portraits don't bother the subject at
> all--I read somewhere that the mother in *The Liar's Club,* a very raw
> family memoir published a few years ago (blanking on the author's name)
> loved the book (even though it shows her ignoring sexual molestation of
her
> daughter, going crazy and piling the family furniture in a bonfire, etc.)
> So you never know how the people you write about will react.
>
> The best discussion of this ethical dilemma I've read is in Philip
Gerard's
> *Creative Nonfiction,* especially pages 150-53, "The Confidence of Family
> and Friends" and nearby pages.  He suggests that you show each piece to
the
> people you're writing about.  The dangers are obvious, including their
> making unreasonable objections and your making things worse if you publish
> over their objections.  But they could also make suggestions that
strengthen
> the piece.  It's a tough call, and you say you don't know how to contact
the
> boyfriend, so it may be impossible anyway.
>
> Speaking as a lawyer, I can only point out that anybody can sue anyone
> anytime over anything.  For a libel suit to succeed, the subject has to be
> identifiable (that's why I suggest changing details), the statements have
to
> be disparaging and untrue, etc.  Your boyfriend isn't a public figure (I
> assume); there are special rules making it harder for them to sue.  But
> there are also new and creative bases for suit, like invasion of privacy
and
> placement in a disparaging light, etc., etc.  Inertia is your best
> protection:  it's unlikely your boyfriend would see the piece, it's
unlikely
> he'd be upset enough and have the energy to sue, a lawyer wouldn't see you
> as a rich enough defendant to be worth suing on contingency, etc.
>
> If it were me, I'd go ahead and revise the piece for publication and send
it
> out.  If you need to tell this story and can tell it with force and style,
> people will want to read it and it will be worth any risks there are.
Good
> luck!
>
> Paula Speck
>
>

Subject:      Fulcrum: an annual of poetry and aesthetics (reposted as plain
              text)

Sorry about reposting this -- this time as plain text, so it doesn't get =
garbled in the digest and the archive. -- PN
___

Fulcrum: an annual of poetry and aesthetics (ISSN 1534-7877) is an =
international literary and philosophical journal published by Fulcrum =
Annual.

Editors: Philip Nikolayev, Katia Kapovich

Editorial address: Fulcrum, 334 Harvard Street, Suite D-2, Cambridge, MA =
02139, USA. Phone 617-864-7874. E-mail editor@fulcrumpoetry.com (queries =
only).

The first issue's central theme is "A Map of English-language Poetry." =
It contains poems and essays by leading poets and critics representing =
twelve different parts of the English-speaking world. Twelve out of the =
issue's 16 essays discuss the current poetic situations in those =
regions. Issue One is 256 pages, 6x9, elegantly produced, perfectbound =
with a glossy cover and exquisite black-and-white cover and internal =
art, printed on 50# White Offset paper.

Contributors: by Douglas Barbour (Canada), Ken Bolton (Australia), Pam =
Brown (Australia), Branston Clark (Belize, USA), Fred D'Aguiar (Guyana, =
England, USA), Allen Fisher (England), Randolph Healy (Ireland), Brian =
Henry (USA), W. N. Herbert (Scotland), Peter Horn (South Africa), Robert =
Kelly (USA), David Kennedy (England), John Kinsella (Australia), August =
Kleinzahler (USA), Alan Loney (New Zealand), Paul Muldoon (Northern =
Ireland), Gregory O'Brien (New Zealand), Marjorie Perloff (USA), =
Sheenagh Pugh (Wales), Menka Shivdasani (India), Matvey Yankelevich =
(USA), Angeline Yap (Singapore), Harriet Zinnes (USA).

Subscription rates in the U.S. are $12 per issue/year for individuals, =
$15 for institutions. Foreign subscriptions are $17 and $20 =
respectively. $5 discount for a three-year subscription. A check, money =
order or bank draft drawn in U.S. dollars and payable to Fulcrum Annual =
should be sent to Fulcrum, 334 Harvard Street, Suite D-2, Cambridge, MA =
02139, USA. Booksellers please use the contact info below to find out =
about our house discount.

Fulcrum welcomes submissions of poetry and essays on poetry, poets, =
poetic form, the philosophy of poetry, poetics, aesthetics and related =
subjects (no reviews). Read Fulcrum before submitting work. Unsolicited =
submissions are read June through August only and must be accompanied by =
a return envelope with sufficient postage or IRCs if a response is =
desired.

While I think there is, alas,  some truth in Joel's comments,
about the limits of much American poetry viz-a-viz other countries---
but I think you make big jump when you speak of "the luxury to experiment"
(which you do qualify in your penultimate sentence)--
There's definitely a class tension within America on which this is played out
as well...
and it's partially why the "avant-garde" vs. "mainstream" thing is so Bush-vs.
Gore
while the most talked about (published, reviewed, etc.) of both ilks do seem to

be less generous about the usual first person conceits, etc....
that it seems that when some Americans do write in that way that you talk of
that non-Western poets do, that they are considered not sophisticated enough
(and actually there's a bit of a double standard in a lot of poetry
officialdoms in the SA
---it's okay for someone from another country to do so, but not for an
American---
actually PAUL VANGELISTI'S introduction to BARAKA'S transbluecency touches on
this...)

On another level, it's also a matter of reading and interpretation more than
writing---
say the way that many read many blues songs as mostly about a MALE just
complaing about
a FEMALE, but it can also be read more generously---at times very much seems
the "female" is placeholder for Racist America, etc....well in the male songs,
and yeah
not always...and, no, I'm not trying to say that the "personal" isn't often
more profound
than the "political"---Should probably write an essay again, but just thought
I'd chime in....

Basically I agree with much you say, but the idea of America education as
privilege and luxury
I think needs to be complicated....

take care,
chris

Joel Weishaus wrote:

> > I was waiting for someone to ask this question.  The answer, of course, is

> Bill:
>
> There's somewhat of a cultural quandary here, as most Americans, certainly
> its educated, if not over-educated, poets, grow up in a privileged space.
> Your home is probably not in jeopardy of suddenly being hit by a (American
> made) missile, and you're not concerned that when you go shopping someone
> will blow you up. Most poets in the Third World don't have the luxury to
> experiment like Western poets do. Unlike most Western poets, many Third
> World poets speak not so much for themselves as for the sufferings and
> aspirations of their people. Their poems, then, are more generous than the
> usual first person conceits we find in much Western poetry today. (In some
> cases, the first person implies something larger, but I'm not talking to
> that.) On the other hand, all worthwhile poems are experimental. It's just
> that some are more constrained than others.
>

tiffany


there were ghosts, tiffany and honey, when clara hielo internet ruled
behind dark eyes, illuminated wires, and tiffany and honey and travis, or
for a while, leaped up and ran the house. she'll be back later, tiffany.
hielo internet, tiffany, alan, claire, honey, and others, tiffany, in
particular, relation say to tiffany forever. as long as tiffany will
speak, i will listen. i swear it. @describe lance as holed skin, rimmed
with tiffanyalan or clitoral double cones, flattened, holed with clitoral,
intensity of tiffanyalan, hole. the hole in the craggy hollow, hello
tiffany, i see tiffany worries about the meaning of life. tiffany makes a
quaint, magical gesture with one hand. tiffany has created the herbalist..
tiffany smiles happily. tiffany points whatever s/he or anyone proffers as
the real. so says tiffany honey clarissa shulamit margarita catherine
tiffany no longer call her own a plain with tiffany of white crows black
sky clarissa evacuation of anal, stumbled clitoris of tiffany, burrowed
plains, tiffany eats a dagger. tiffany eats the corpse. tiffany becomes
queen of everything in the lpmud of tiffany. the hole. the hole in the
lpmud of tiffany. the hole. the hole in the datagrams, the sound.

<tiffany> hold it

<tiffany> thinking is exhaustion.

<tiffany> the sun makes difference

<tiffany> they end the process, sleep during the night when dreams

<tiffany> nothing means but when thinking exhausts, meaning appears.

tiffany says you chop tiffany to pieces! ah! the blood! your blood freezes
as men and women hear tiffany's death cry. tiffany appears with an ear-
splitting bang. tiffany exclaims "you killed me!" you drop the bones of
alan, it is enough that you were thinking.

<tiffany> that it would have given information and

tiffany says, in a light later, these will be known as the real. so says
tiffany honey clarissa shulamit margarita catherine tiffany no longer call
her own a plain with tiffany of white crows black sky clarissa evacuation
of anal, stumbled clitoris of tiffany, burrowed plains, tiffany eats a
dagger. tiffany eats the corpse. tiffany becomes queen of everything in
the datagrams, the sound.

tiffany says 'did you kill orc?' tiffany says 'i've been eating lots of
food here' tiffany grins evilly. tiffany eats the corpse. tiffany becomes
queen of everything in the midst of the other. eyes; in turn, she snapped
tiffany's wrist as if it were paper. bones

> everything turns to liquid; everything flows, cauterizes. the corrosive

> always elsewhere, always others. we are blind beneath the surface; we

> of others; we claw through it back to our original face; the tongue, nub
> of the parenthetical, holding at bay, beyond the pale, what is most
> feared, that of indiscriminate fucking, desire penetrating beyond the
> pale, what is most feared, that of indiscriminate fucking, desire
> penetrating beyond the criminality of the other, chthonic domain, is
> always elsewhere, always others. we are alone among the missing, the
> greater our passions, our arousals, the less our signifiers remain; we
> flow like wax into you, taking your impressions. it's politics. it
> transforms into the fantasm of an originary state. sex is a foundation,
> originary impulse; only that it retro-projects into the fantasm, withdraws
> from the nub re-enters the nub; what the nub is the same against the same;
> the nub re-enters the nub; what the nub is the emergence of the imaginary,
> turns our images into part-objects, spreads us across your magnetic
> domains, your optical domains, your fiber optics, your twisted copper
> wires. nothing touches anything; the drives are sealed, abjection without.
> what we have is our presence in the cosmos; we can feel the weight of our
> head turned to one side or another, the explosive gasp of air (surfacing),
> the violent inhalation (going down once again). we are always among the
> missing. the greater our passions, our arousals, the less our signifiers
> remain; we flow like wax into you, taking your impressions. it's politics,
> it transforms into the flesh of other's; we claw through it back to our
> original face is flesh. in "our" work, this trembling scatters; objects
> return to part-objects without memory of the parenthetical, holding at
> bay, beyond the criminality of the world, the choratic stuttering into the
> construct of space and time. eventually it doesn't need anything at all,
> neither body nor viewer, writer nor reader. plasma curls the screen, turns
> hard drives into replete translations, fills hard drives into replete
> translations, fills hard drives with catalysts of the w/hole. the images /
> videos / texts exist on the basin is to gnaw through to emptiness. within
> the aegis of gravity, gravitas, it can flood through all pronouncement. it
> draws you in. sex curls the screen, turns hard drives into replete
> translations, fills hard drives into replete translations, fills hard
> drives with catalysts of the subject absorbed by the trembling of the real
> which is always in emergence. in "our" work is as explicit as possible. it
> is not the reduction of 0*S nor the semiotic; it is all of the nub. the
> material of the world is a matter of pressure; substance is the semiosis
> of the other, chthonic domain, is always in emergence. in "our" work, we
> work the original face. we play against technology, memory, direct and

> grip.

In a message dated 7/24/02 3:30:28 PM, weishaus@PDX.EDU writes:

<< > I was waiting for someone to ask this question.  The answer, of course,

Bill:


There's somewhat of a cultural quandary here, as most Americans, certainly

its educated, if not over-educated, poets, grow up in a privileged space.

Your home is probably not in jeopardy of suddenly being hit by a (American

made) missile, and you're not concerned that when you go shopping someone

will blow you up. Most poets in the Third World don't have the luxury to

experiment like Western poets do. Unlike most Western poets, many Third

World poets speak not so much for themselves as for the sufferings and

aspirations of their people. Their poems, then, are more generous than the

usual first person conceits we find in much Western poetry today. (In some

cases, the first person implies something larger, but I'm not talking to

that.) On the other hand, all worthwhile poems are experimental. It's just

that some are more constrained than others.


-Joel

 >>

Joel, I couldn't agree more.  By the way, as I'm sure you know, not all
poetry created without American privilege limits itself to first person
strategies, generous or not.  Tinkering with familiar devices goes on
everywhere.  If the original claim on this list was that the Avant-Garde
"breaks down" during wartime, then that seems true only within privileged
spaces.  The claim speaks, once again, to the desire on the part of a few to
co-opt the Avant-Garde, to exclude from it all writing that engages the
trajectory of individual experience, of actual day to day life.  For example,
one very well known writer told me recently that in order to be Avant-Garde,
one must exorcise all emotion from art -- a very narrow focus indeed.  I can
certainly understand how the these sorts of experiments might take a back
seat during wartime.  But as you suggest, there is more than one way to
experiment, to be Avant-Garde.  Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com

Date:         Thu, 25 Jul 2002 10:25:38 EDT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

In a message dated 7/24/02 12:53:22 PM, rcor@U.WASHINGTON.EDU writes:

<< And the academy is pretty resistant to disjunction:  it took Williams
forever to get into the canon, Stein even longer, and Djuna Barnes got
there maybe five years ago.
 >>

May I jump in?  This is interesting.  I don't think disjunction is
necessarily the issue.  Eliot, Joyce, Faulkner, even Burroughs entered the
canon fairly quickly.  Yes, Burroughs.  It has been near impossible to bury
him since Mailer set him on his throne -- a good thing since he's brilliant.
It's now a question of politics and influence rather than of aesthetic
methodology, and has been for quite a while.  That said, I agree that in a
few modern cases, such as that of Stein, radical disjunction has taken a
while to sink in, to make its value known to those who happen to wield power
at the time.  But this is not a bad thing.  Work that does not easily
translate remains open to contextualization, i.e., future contexts.  Such
texts are, one hopes, never totalized, never "read" so completely that they
lose their textuality.  Hemingway's texts, for example (despite their
brilliance) seem bound by a moment in history precisely because they are so
easily read, so easily "translated."  Stein's are not.  One may argue that
Hemingway's texts are therefore more historical than Stein's.  But it all
depends on one's point of view.  I would argue that Hemingway's texts deny
history, deny context, in a way that Stein's don't.  In opening themselves to
contextualization, Stein's texts open themselves to history.  Who is the
better artist is another issue altogether, but nonetheless wrought with
contingencies, as are all judgments of quality.  Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com

Hi Tom

This incredible co-opting mechanism came of age in the late 1960's. If any
idea becomes too controversial, effective marketing mainstreams the form
while diluting the content. In effect, it's OK to rattle a saber that can't
slice butter.

Vernon
