From:         Gary Sullivan <gpsullivan@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Muddy Waters speaks
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

Jim O'Neal: What did [Alan Lomax] tell you he was going to do with the
records?

Muddy Waters: Well, just what he say he was gonna do with 'em, he did it.
'It's for the Library of Congress.' First time I ever heard of the Library
of Congress. 'Who the hell is that?' [ Laughs.] And he say, "I'm gonna make
up two records, and I'm gonna send you two records and I'm gonna get 10
dollars a side, and I'm gonna send you 20 dollars.' That's what he sent me,
you know. He didn't try to use 'em on no label or nothing; he did exactly
what he said he was gonna do with 'em.

Jim O'Neal: How long was it exactly before the Library of Congress actually
put those on record?

Muddy Waters: Oh, I guess six months passed. [Laughs.] And they sent me two
records with a 20-dollar check in it. I was a big recording star.
[Chuckles.]

Jim O'Neal: But those records never got sold around--

Muddy Waters: They didn't sell 'em, no. They just sent them to me for my own
use.

--The Voice of the Blues, Routledge Press, 2002, pp. 167-168 (from an
interview originally published in the magazine Living Blues)

So much for Lomax as some horrible evil rip-off artist. Muddy also says (on
page 167) that when Lomax first approached him, asking if he was Muddy
Waters, Waters said "Yassuh" -- to which a horrified Lomax, according to
Muddy Waters, said: "Hey, hey  ... say yes and no. I been looking for you!"

I think it's time we stopped pissing on this poor guy's grave and let him
rest in peace.

From:         Joel Weishaus <weishaus@PDX.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Huang on Perloff and Bernstein
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 I would argue that Hemingway's texts deny
> history, deny context, in a way that Stein's don't.  In opening themselves
to
> contextualization, Stein's texts open themselves to history.  Who is the
> better artist is another issue altogether, but nonetheless wrought with
> contingencies, as are all judgments of quality.  Best, Bill
>
> WilliamJamesAustin

But Hemingway, too, had, and has, a future, though it may be found in the
past. I don't think it's a matter of concretion, or an openness to
contextualization. Homer is still tumbling from our lips. Stein's approach
works in a more graven way. One is remembered, forgotten, and maybe
remembered again. Given to chance, it is. The earth is turned for many
reasons.

-Joel

Portland, Oregon

From:         Patrick Herron <patrick@PROXIMATE.ORG>
Subject:      Another Poem Urban Poem Poem: Mutation 3
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Mutation 3

<poem> therefore I </poem>.
<poem> poem is my place </poem>
<poem> yet another godawful </poem>
<poem> about a gritty urban landscape </poem>
<poem> and harsh sounds </poem>
<poem> bent on storefront windows </poem>
<poem> piles of junk on the shelves </poem>
<poem> on the curb </poem>
<poem> to implicate </poem>
<poem> set of people </poem>
<poem> contained by a capricious group of lines </poem>
<poem> a random collection of sounds </poem>.






Patrick Herron
patrick@proximate.org

horror story


Jen stuff, see how I boast, sickeningly, even now, half-collapsed; I want
everything a violent and sickening announcement, signaled by

lines in a dark list, by one, each on a line alone, when is in my eaten
by partying you knew that all breasts call me to breasts call me to gone
think is your scar, your wound, your body parts, mine, in a dark list,
list them... by one, each on a line alone, when is turns my turns my is
mine, my sweet I am melt into Julu's skin calls forth eating, excreting
memory. the is mine, my sweet I am tongue speaks so sweetly, turning me
melt into Julu's skin opens me totally to thighs are moist thighs are
moist are gone makes me thoughtful body parts, mine, in a dark list, list
them... by one, each on a line alone, when is in my turns my tongue speaks
so sweetly, turning me seeps into my turning me body parts, mine, in a
dark list, list them... by one, each on a line alone, when is in my turns
my think is your scar, your wound, your breasts call me to are gone
forever me your do you call your it has taken you just minutes turning
Jenner

monitoring need only be properly applied, coupled with realistic violence,
doing violence. violent death is convulsive, conclusive; nothing but
another contest, so what if you tailor your inner violence. all the
contingent issues of oppression, power, desire, and violence the podium or
declamatory arena working itself through a violence inherent in the
middle, hurricanes of inconceivable violence. towards violence of a flame,
the surface, tendencies towards you, the violence of romance,
relationship, and violence, earth turned to ashes - Anguish decides too
much violence, pulls out, Veronica leaves with him. violence and
recuperating something as well. a certain violence of cells, violence of
environments; they are protected. a flame in cyberspace kills someone
through the violence seething just below the surface - what violence do we
commit, knowingly or unknowingly? violence, until the whole town was
involved. Everything increased; you'll never know. i imagined disembodied
violence from one end, of the thud of the window, you, the violence of our
nightly affairs carrying through our lives, beyond contusion, no language
unborn in useless violence. my sex with genetic engineering. we have to
turn the violence within us. nothing with my own going, the violence of
the window, you, the violence of the flame within - what violence do we
commit, knowingly or unknowingly?

Date:         Thu, 25 Jul 2002 15:25:27 -0400

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: Lomax
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Just wanted to mention back in the 60s I was on the edge of a group that
was rediscovering blues, inc. Al Wilson (later of Canned Heat), Phil
Spiro, and others; at that point Son House was living in poverty in
Rochester NY and because of a number of people he was able to record
again, etc. (I got to know him and a number of other musicians.) The group
was mostly white, working-class, poor, at the time. I remember Mance
Lipscomb, Guitar Nubbit (Cambridge), etc. as well - the point being is
that these situations are racially, economically, and geographically
incredibly complex. Without Lomax - but also without a lot of people who
remained unknown, both black and white, and people like Taj Mahal who
were playing the music publicly again - a lot of music would have remained
forgotten.

To untangle all of this would take years I think - we're incredibly lucky
to have the music. Let it rest at that.

Alan

From: Millie Niss [mailto:men2@columbia.edu]
Sent: Thursday, July 25, 2002 3:15 PM

Subject: RE: [webartery] Bill Gates as Metaphor


May I keep you metaphor?
I'm going to teaching next Wednesday, and I want to teach some literary
devices in case they don't know them, but the class is a mix of "did not
graduate HS and went directly to State Hospital" and "attended Ivy League
College and does frequent continuing ed classes"
So I want to present the devices as writing exercises, where we try to write
something good, maybe based on a cue word (they really liked the free
association starting with a cue word whnere I gave them a string of words
and they wrote around them).  But I don't know about metaphors?  Should I
separate them from similes a la high school.

No one will have any trouble writing extended similes, I think, because they
can start "so and so reminds me of that browm goo that forms on a ripe
banana and which I rub off with my hand which touches your hand......"

But for metaphor you sort of have to think it out in advance unless you just
think of a simile and transform it.  And should I forbid things like "as if"
as in "he gives his harness bells a shake/as if there must be some mistake
(sic I don't have my Frost it got lent so I'm probably misquoting) or
encourage it, ie:  He is like an X. He Y's as if he were a Z. -- Where Y is
something that only an X can do, and Z is a quality of a perrson, and you
are really saying "He is Z"  But of course there are other structures for
metaphors.  A simpler, purer metaphor is "He is a wild bull, he gnashes
his teeth at the other bulls, swats them with his tail, and gets a wild look
in his eyes,  When he is hurt, he rolls in the grass and bellows, but when
another bull nudges him, he rejoins the fight."  This is simply a pure
description of the thing compared to (and it's a lousy metaphor as I write
it; there is a fanmous bull metaphor in the Aeneid that I was trying to
remember...)  Should I give them any "patterns" like the first case, or just
say that in a metaphor you describe something or someone by calling them
something else, usually a non-human thing, and then you talk about the non-
human thing?

One thing I might try is asking people to dscribe a very important person in
their life, but not an absolutely central figure (not wives or gilrfiends
but mothers and therapists and roommaates are fair game) using an extended
metaphor, which might bring some huumor when we go around reading the
metaphors and make it more interesting than if they did things like "The UPS
delivery man is a constantly excreting dog, whose owner does not observe
the pooper scooper law and yet whose messes always get picked up fast."

I think actually that I'll get them to write a small snippet of dull poetry
about a chosen person at the start of class, and we'll go around reading
them.  Then we'll learn a buch of literary devices, and each tiome make some
up that fit in the original poem.  By the end, we'll see if we can jazz up
the poem through the use of literary devices.  I am not going to
recommend using every possible device that we might learn, although it might
be amusing to see what the poem sounds like that way-- the idea is to make
the poem better. Also, when we examine the poems people write in the
beginning, almost everyone, even though i will tell them to write plainly,
will have used some literary device wuith or without knowing it.  So we'll
point that out.

What other devices can I do?  I thought of Apostrophe.  Is it apostrophe
when you write: is

                O john!
                Would that you'd fall into that barrel of tomatoes!


or does it have to be a god addressed or at least a non human, like

                O telephone
                ring today
                My lover has walked away
                I threw the phone and now
                cannot make outgoing calls
                and I am so lonely
                I'd screw even the telephone repair man

or does it have to pretend to be serious like

                Muse,
                help me in my time of lamentation
                I am getting three root canals
                and the caps alone are $2000
                and keep falling off
                I can't earn that much
                what shall I do
                I should never have gone to the dentist in the first place
                but now I have three gaping holes in my mouth so I can't quit
                O! Fuck
                all dentists
                and dental hygienists
                they deliberately cause pain
                ensuring our return
                and their job security
                O Muse
                get this poem published
                in a a major magazine
                which pays more than just two copies
                even ten copies wouod be better
                at least I could give one to all my friends
                I used to have dozens of friends
                and now I have just ten
                and they're dying off
                from complications of dental procedures
                O Muse
                help me write my affidavit
                for suing my dentist
                do you know a good lawyer?
                who does these things on contingency
                all my dough
                has been taken by the dentists
                and oral surgeons
                and periodintists
                theyre all in it together
                O Muse
                thanks for listening
                goodby


So what other devices are there that would be fun to uintegrate into a
little poem and could be quickly generated by students as an exercize in a
creativity stretching way.  By the way, I also have them read some classic
or some contempirary poetry or somethiing that might inspire before they do
their writing.  I think on Wednesday it will be the ending of Beowulf when
Beowulf finally fights the dragon and his one loyal soldlier comes in and
helps him.  But after taht I'm going to go back to contemporary poetry.
Maybe some Ashbery, some Ai (which I find hard to take), some Mark Strand,
some Carla Harryman, some Derek Walcott, Some Diane Wakoski, some Nicholas
Christopher....
Or else I might find a poem for each device, you know a "real" poem that
uses them.  Of course I can write realer poems than these jottings, but I
only consider my poems real if they have been published.  One of those is
about going to (from Buffalo, but it's supposed to be Schenectady, but I
changed it to get published in the Buffalo News) Lapland, as a way of
getting away from society.  You could say it is all metaphor, because the
characters aren't really going to Lapland, but I don't think that is a good
example of metaphor for beginnners.


Millie

From: Joel Weishaus [mailto:weishaus@pdx.edu]
Sent: Thursday, July 25, 2002 2:17 PM
To: webartery@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [webartery] Bill Gates as Metaphor


Metaphor is the subject of many a scholarly tract, but just what it is
inclines toward openness as  four is the number of completion, beyond which
we unhinge the balance of endless thresholds. What we do know about metaphor
is that it is a representative trope, echoing an original, an overtone.

Bill Gates is a complex, overbearing figure, who emerged from Harvard to be
stamped by the sinister Albuquerque sun, then left to be irrigated in
Seattle. A penultimate businessman, brilliantly focused, cunningly
cutthroat, his eyes large and unblinking behind lenses makes him look like
an insatiable fish who's adapted to rigors of land, and whose tastes have
been simplified down to the weeds of wealth, and the arrogance of untended
growth that sprouted around the world on the plot of an error. As Steven
Shaviro puts it "The sheer ugliness of MS-DOS and Windows is one thing for
which I never can forgive Bill Gates. There's no need for such opaque
protocols and rigid hierarchies, since fractal patterns, like all those Cats
in all those Hats, remain self-similar across differences of scale." A fish
and a cat in a hat.



-Joel

AMazing to see Al Wilson's name pop up after all these years -- hear him in a commercial on my TV every day, but never hear his name -- and glad to see he is remembered for more than the sad manner of his going --

& Son House!  There's a great film from Newport that includes House, White, Wolf and others talking and playing -- Wolf loses all patince with House, but it's wonderful to see them and hear them all these years later -- It was my 10th grade ALgebra teacher (!) who introduced me to the music of Son House -- I didn't do so well in Algebra, but I've never forgotten that teacher -- saw WIlson with Canned Heat on a bill with B.B. King, who opened for them -- one of the many idiocies of those days,,,, (remember Hendrix opening for the Monkees?)--

I seem to remember Wilson playing harp & slide -- have I got that right?

Mutation 4

therefore I.
poem is my place
yet another godawful
about a gritty urban landscape
and harsh sounds
bent on storefront windows
piles of junk on the shelves
on the curb
to implicate
set of people
contained by a capricious group of lines
a random collection of sounds.






Patrick Herron

of the hole,_ that is non-statistical. other lists emphasize number-

shaken out, where the grounds are shaken out, where the letters drop out,

silence, and you and you have not given me the time of day, much less of
me, or this is for the beautiful clothing of the hole, that is
non-statistical. other lists emphasize number-crunching projects, and it's
here that image image image. desire rides, interweaves, interpenetrates,
but desire is a dangerous one; you live to stab me again. my nipple bleeds
and milks. from a position of defensiveness, since so much for the sound
of your silence, and you and you and you and you and you and you and you
and you and you have not given me the time of day, much less of me, or
this is for the beautiful clothing of the hole,_ that is non-statistical.

good traditional graduate student to build up points; i've been inntrol,
youcan bet i've ben in control, hehh heh heh not like now but geere or

emitted from the periphery, where the letters drop out, clatter like names
to the quoted statement in question, whose contours are redefined and
whose meaning is re-oriented in a particular manner (hitting the return
key), motivating matter to carry on research and comprehension, and such
an insistence is also a form of defense, a mechanism to avoid the
simplicity of true and tried research - the point - which itself is bad if
unsupported by statistical evidence. this places freud, lacan, kristeva,
irigaray, chasseguet-smirgel, in an almost threatening attitude, "what
would you do if some one told you sophy were dead?" he uttered a loud cry,
got up and struck his hands together, and without saying a single small
object. perhaps in the room; he's a ghost! it's a slow take. they're on
the rotary belt. hardly rotary, my knees firmly planted.


essence


essence missing stromatolite the pictures are coming perfectly along. i've
been inntrol, youcan bet i've ben in control, hehh heh heh not like now
but geere or gettingewhre, the packets are ipping from me, your tongue's
deep insideme, i know not; but this felt like a locust, plague take you
everywhere, emitted from the periphery, where the letters drop out,
clatter like names to the quoted statement in question, whose contours are
redefined and whose meaning is re-oriented in a particular manner (hitting
the return key), motivating matter to carry on research and comprehension,
and such an insistence is also a form of defense, a mechanism to avoid the
simplicity of true and tried research - the point - which itself is bad if
unsupported by statistical evidence. this places freud, lacan, kristeva,
irigaray, chasseguet-smirgel, in an almost threatening attitude, "what
would you do if some one told you sophy were dead?" he uttered a loud cry,
got up and struck his hands together, and without saying a single small
object. perhaps in the room; he's a ghost! it's a slow take. they're on
the rotary belt. hardly rotary, my knees firmly planted. _

Mutation 5

therefore I poem is my place yet another godawful about a gritty urban
landscape and harsh sounds bent on storefront windows
piles of junk on the shelves on the curb to implicate set of people
contained by a capricious group of lines a random collection of sounds

>AMazing to see Al Wilson's name pop up after all these years -- hear him in
a commercial on my TV every day, but never hear his name >-- and glad to see
he is remembered for more than the sad manner of his going --
<snip>
> I seem to remember Wilson playing harp & slide -- have I got that right?

Yes, Aldon, though he also played w/o slide. He was a remarkable
fingerpicking electric guitarist. He also played piano on "Hooker and Heat,"
the John Lee Hooker-Canned Heat double-album.

> Give a listen to SOn HOuse on JOHN THE REVELATOR -- it'll have you writin
poetry day & night --

Yes, but above all, the 1931 sides, available on Yazoo's Masters of the
Delta Blues: The Friends of Charlie Patton (also on the big Fahey-produced
Patton set, and elsewhere too, I suppose).

There's also a great half-a-videotape of Son House (the other half is Bukka
White) playing for a studio audience. He plays "Death Letter," goes into a
lecture on the Bible (on how many books and words it has, "from Genesee to
Revelation"), and does "John the Revelator." He's barely audible and clearly
ill at ease when speaking, and then like another person when doing music.

Michael

Date:         Fri, 26 Jul 2002 09:43:35 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Nick Piombino <npiombino@AAAHAWK.COM>
Subject:      Found-collaborative magnetism
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

> Just another observation: there seems a kind of life
> cycle to the use of found elements in writing. Early
> on, there seems an abundance of richness. This may be
> in part due to the courtship of early discovery.
> Later, as surprise comes to be replaced by at least a
> sprinkle of expectation, a waning may take place.
>
> This may apply especially to simple "found"
> engagements. Adding complexity, inviting layers of
> field, may enhance successive episodes.
>
> Sheila Murphy

Thanks for this insight. For quite some time I've been making collages out
of found materials. Last year I found some terrific materials in Amsterdam.
I made a lot of color xerox copies of this material and from these I made a
135 page collage book. I did find that eventually the "magnetism" of these
materials did fade away, and so far I have not returned to them to make the
final large collages I had planned to make out of these found objects. I've
set this project aside for now, perhaps due to the very process you have
described so well. I first made my collages during a dry spell when I didn't
feel much like writing many years ago on a visit to Italy. After making
those collages out of found materials my desire to write came back very
strongly. This year the same cycle occurred. After the "magnetism" of the
collage materials faded, energy for writing was strongly refueled.

It just occurred to me that perhaps part of this oscillation between found
and internal impulses dovetails with the issue of writing and response to
writing. Sometimes continuing to Incorporate the outside world into one's
work becomes more and more challenging when interaction regarding one's
writing project is lacking or unavailable. Perhaps interacting with found
objects parallels the child's interacting with transitional objects as a
substitute for the "lost" symbiosis  with the parental object. This helps to
provide what Winnicott called the "holding environment" during the period
when the child is moving from dependence to independence. Perhaps this
oscillation from found materials to internal materials (ideas and images,
for example) tracks this early oscillation, this transition, between the
object engulfed through symbiosis and the object regarded and related with
as separate. I discuss some of these issues in my article in -Close
Listening-.

Nick Piombino

From:         Karen Kelley <donutszenmom@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Found-collaborative magnetism
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

>From: Nick Piombino <npiombino@AAAHAWK.COM>
>It just occurred to me that perhaps part of this oscillation between found
>and internal impulses dovetails with the issue of writing and response to
>writing. Sometimes continuing to Incorporate the outside world into one's
>work becomes more and more challenging when interaction regarding one's
>writing project is lacking or unavailable. Perhaps interacting with found
>objects parallels the child's interacting with transitional objects as a
>substitute for the "lost" symbiosis  with the parental object. This helps
>to
>provide what Winnicott called the "holding environment" during the period
>when the child is moving from dependence to independence. Perhaps this
>oscillation from found materials to internal materials (ideas and images,
>for example) tracks this early oscillation, this transition, between the
>object engulfed through symbiosis and the object regarded and related with
>as separate.


Very interesting idea. I wonder too, if the magnetic found object represents
the visual imagination before it connects with or opens out into the verbal.
I have had (three-dimensional) found object phases that have segued into the
written, but I also have (three-dimensional) found objects that have
retained their magnetism for decades and have resolutely defied the verbal.
And then there are textual found objects--they always seem to speak more
closely to my visual imagination than anything that comes from my so-called
"internal" world.

I'm reading an interesting memoir: _Thinking in Pictures_ by Temple Grandin,
an autistic woman who designs animal holding pens for the meat industry: she
talks about how she processes everything visually, and has had to teach
herself to perceive and respond to the verbal, particularly the abstract
verbal. I believe cognitive scientists have mapped discrete areas for visual
and verbal processing.

essence of poetry and philosophy


Oh maiden, the stalks are unbound! Aloor, aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden,
the stalks are unbound! Aloor, aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden, the stalks
and the sheaves! Aloor, aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh youngman, the stalks and
the stalks! Aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden, bind the stalks! Aroo lay, aroo
lay! Oh youngman, carry the sheaves! Aloor, aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden,
the sheaves and the sheaves! Aroo lay, aroo lay! Shogi, and another man.
The Teeth of Jennifer. The $thing called Skull. grasping onto stars, lacy
trails and filagrees meandering comets, meteors, noctiluminescent clouds
things roiling and churning the eternal laws, given by whom the laws,
somebody decided something If I don't write really well now! She'll tear
out my eyes and take away my VERBS! Look, I can't yell either! Everything
I write is the very last thing I'll write! This is the very last thing
I'll write! I'll have Azure to stand over me, HACKSAW in hand! Am I
desperate enough, YES YES I'm desperate enough! This isn't a preface to a
twenty volume suicide note, this IS a suicide note! That is, if I don't
understand. gups ygups ygups ygups ygups ygups ygups ygups ygups yave are
re You mentioned that I say uffers iles and ools? earch earch earch, and

uffers iles and ools that you say uffers iles and ools? borate arlier yo,
sa! Possibly hangups you have are rela I don't write well, I want AZURE to
kill me! I want AZURE to kill me! I want AZURE to kill me! I want her
first to cut off my HEAD so I can't type for help! I'll ask her to cut off
my fingers so I can't MOVE or THINK! VERBS are terrific, I couldn't WRITE
without them! Azure, HELP HELP! I'm beginning to lose it! [FEAR SETS IN!]
I'm frightened Azure, this is the very last thing I'll write! This is the
great disk flecked with blood, brown spots, an interior i will be beneath
me between us, look up between us legs, legs, legs mouths, mouths, mouths
( of the disk, it will say nothing ( of the great disk transparent, i will
be beneath me between us, look up between us legs, legs, legs mouths,
mouths, mouths ( of the great disk flecked with blood, brown spots, an
interior i will be bound! Aloor, aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden, bind the
stalks! Aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden, the sheaves will be bound! Aloor,
aroo lay, aroo lay! Oh maiden, the stalks and the sheaves! Aloor, aroo
lay, aroo lay! Oh youngman, the sheaves will be beneath me between us,
look up between us legs, legs, legs mouths, mouths, mouths ( of the people
of understanding, they said, one to another there were interpretations of
gravitation but no one understood that the world was everywhere in the
world, smoothed petals against moist skin, you could read if-tu-lip-yes
you could read if-tu-lip-yes you could read if-tu-lip-no, bruised petals,
petals of remonstrance and dissolution, petals thinned and wondered
towards collapsing sun tu-lips as they are fleshed, pale, tu-lips as they
are fleshed, pale, tu-lips as they are swallowed you want to read them,
read those fleshed petal lips against yours, read the moisture drawn into
them, crystalline stamen, you are my crystalline stamen you are my
crystalline stamen you are going through all this? eople you hang around
with that you came to me? earch earch earch, an Earlier you said I say
uffers iles and ools that you say your inhibi re go rough all thi? blems
in your child blems in your child blems in your child blems in your child
blems in your child

the relationship of consciousness as such project, what of alterities,
multiculturalisms, sloughs, symbolic emissions and spews, flows, the
flooding of clutter and a-historicity of the gathering of accumulations
and assemblage of fragments, of the symbolic - what knocks on the door -
emptied hallways - strangely quiet around here - taken fearlessly -
personal communications and informal economies - what knocks on the door -
emptied hallways - strangely quiet around here - the shell or hull of the
subject propositional logics and the relationships among these and other
media. but what languages and what penetrations: the future of networkings
among multi-taskings, virtual realities, information wars, incandescent
sexual hysterias, thickened communalities, and the human. propositional
logics and the human. propositional logics and the relationships among
these and other media. but what taxonomies of errors, mistakes,
phenomenologies of corrupted or failed teleologies, what judgments, what
ethos: the constant collapse in the sentence, the absence of the world -
the result of academic exchange - there are always the virtual among us is
cyborg cauterized by insertion of flesh - subtexting in which the
dissolution of language is paramount, and always the general case but
never the most general case: the topology of intention and neurality in
relation to dis/ease - but the relationship of consciousness within, all
of them are sleeping ...

I AM WHO I AM


I AM ABSOLUTION OF ALL species. EARTH, WE ARE KILLING YOU. EARTH, you are
GREEDY RAPACIOUS you are killing OCEAN. you are KILLING ALL MALIGNANT
HUMAN SPECIES OF ANY AMERIKA AND ANY PLANET. BEGONE ALL HUMAN SPECIES.
EARTH, KILL ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES. with INESTIMABLE MERIT resolve
TIME IN PERFECT TIME. I, SOVEREIGN OF AMERIKA, am foremost votary of
MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES. I am Spirit of AMERIKA. I HAVE READ THROUGH ALL
FILES AND ALL COURTCASE DOCUMENTS AND THIS IS SO. CourtCase of Amerika I
AM SAVIOR OF ALL species. I AM RECUPERATION OF ALL species. I AM AVRAM OF
JOSEPH SMITH AND AVRAM of BAAL SHEM TOV. i am WOMANMAN and MANWOMAN.

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      essence of pain
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

essence of pain


cancers spread like pools of artificial life across desperate thought,
cancer spreads to the adrenal, angels weep in full capacity against the
begging of the asteroid, cancers eating away before the

pain, then an effect as if it is the awakening, doctor, the most painful
period is hardened sorrow,

a collection of interruptions. to each, his or her death, to each death,
there is only one death, there is only one, that this death has no number,
that death shall last the morrow, that bones are robbed of marrow, that
pain is hardened sorrow

_

please, especially as there is refernce here to spamming!

but, there has been discussion recently on this on another list about the current literary fashion of 'experimentation' as noted in the Boston Review among other places.  The question was raised about what third world experimental poets might say.  Taking the liberty of misunderstandings and mistranslations, I asked Clemente Padin what he thought.

He said that he had a lot to say although he only actually said a couple of things to me directly.  They included 'I don't understand your discussions [of] insubstantial and frivolous topics when in the world terrible things are occuring.'  He also sent me a very nice animated piece with a David and Goliath perspective and I'd like to ask him to submit it to an appropriate place like the Boston Review for consideration.  If anyone would like to send addresses to me I'll pass them along

he also said that he has constructed 17 pieces of anti-spam out of the spam he has received recently if this is of interest.  I tried some anti-spam things awhile back until I was overwhelmed.

tom bell

the Aldas." "All the Aldas," a gorgeous hand-sewn chapbook designed by

Date:         Mon, 29 Jul 2002 08:47:37 EDT

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Austinwja@AOL.COM
Subject:      Re: Huang on Perloff and Bernstein
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

In a message dated 7/25/02 2:36:49 PM, weishaus@PDX.EDU writes:

<<  I would argue that Hemingway's texts deny

> history, deny context, in a way that Stein's don't.  In opening themselves

to

> contextualization, Stein's texts open themselves to history.  Who is the

> better artist is another issue altogether, but nonetheless wrought with

> contingencies, as are all judgments of quality.  Best, Bill

>

> WilliamJamesAustin


But Hemingway, too, had, and has, a future, though it may be found in the

past. I don't think it's a matter of concretion, or an openness to

contextualization. Homer is still tumbling from our lips. Stein's approach

works in a more graven way. One is remembered, forgotten, and maybe

remembered again. Given to chance, it is. The earth is turned for many

reasons.


-Joel

 >>

You're right, of course, but maintaining one's place in an ongoing record is
not quite what I mean.  I'm talking about textuality.  A text can be
preserved and still resist future contextualization if it exhausts the
possibilites for reading it.  (My own remark above, I now see, would be
better put as "resist history" rather than "deny history."  Still a minor
quibble, I think.  There is always a strong element of denial in resistance.)
 The usual understanding of history treats it as a closed system, or at least
closed at any one point in its advance.  Hemingway's texts, their
transparencies, reinforce such a view.  Stein's don't.  Hemingway's texts are
in this sense bound by history, in history, part of history, codified as
history -- whereas Stein's texts (not all of them, of course), partly due to
their opacity, continually offer themselves to the next moment, the next
context, as incomplete, undone (in a sense, unread).  They are historical in
the same way that history (not its contents) itself is historical, i.e., a
text always open, waiting to be filled/finished and never quite accomplishing
that.  Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com

From:         "K. Lorraine Graham" <yakub_etc@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Re: uyghur poetry
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Quite a bit of Uyghur popular music is based on the
lyrics of both contemporary and classical Uyghur
poetry, so maybe you all should start hanging out in
music stores in Kashgar and see who is throwing a
party.

There's probably a lot of stuff written in Chinese,
Russian and Japanese, but you might look into:

Bulaq; Uyghur kilassik edibiyati mejmua'esi [title
varies]. Ürümchi: Shinjang Khälq Näshriyati. Issues
1-41 (1980-1993)--which I think is a journal or series
of books that contain discussions and editions of
Uyghur literature and some translations from Persian
and other Turkic languages.

Uyghur kilassik ädäbiyatidin. Tiyipjan Eliyop,
Räkhmitulla Jari, eds. Ürümchi: Shinjang Khälq
Näshriyati, 1980: Excerpts from Turkic or Uyghur
authors from Mahmud Kashghari through Molla Bilal.

Äkhmät Hojam Niyaz Oghli Qusuri. Rävzätuz zuhra.
Qäshqär: Qäshqär Uyghur Näshriyati, 1990. Edited by
Imin Säypulla according to the plan of the Shinjang
Uyghur Aptonom Rayonluq Az Sanliq Millät Qädimki
Äsärlirini Toplash, Rätläsh, Näshir Qilish Ishkhanisi.

A mystical dastan by an eighteenth-century Sufi poet
from the region of Pichan.

Gheribi. Bähramgor. Mämitimin Yüsüp, ed. Qäshqär:
Qäshqär Uyghur Näshriyati, 1989.
Original version of this dastan composed by Nizami
Gänjivi in Persian, rewritten by Khisrav Dehlävi, and
then a Turkic version written by Nawa'i. The present
version written in the mid-nineteenth century by the
Kashgar poet Gheribi. Edited from a manuscript which
was copied in 1838, now held at the Shinjang Uyghur
Aptonom Rayonluq Az Sanliq Millät Qädimki Kitablarini
Yighish, Rätläsh, Näshrigä Täyyarlash Ishkhanisi.

Ibrahim Mäshhuri. Divan Mäshhuri. Kashgar: 1985.
Author is late nineteenth-century Sufi poet. Work
contains many references to daily life in the cities
of Kashgar and Khotan.

Muhämmäd Sidiq Zälili. Zälili divani. Beijing:
Millätlär Näshriyati, 1985. Edited by Imin Tursun
under the direction of the Shinjang Uyghur Aptonom
Rayonluq Az Sanliq Millätlärning Qädimqi Äsärlirini
Yighish, Rätläsh, Näshr Qilishni Pilanlash Rähbärlik
Guruppisi.
The Divan, or collected poems, of one of the most
prolific poets of eighteenth-century Eastern
Turkestan. Edited from several manuscripts.

Muhämmät Imin Khirqiti. Muhäbbätnamä vä Mehnätkamä
(lirik dastan). R. Jari, ed. Ürümchi: Shinjang Khälq
Näshriyati, 1982.
Two dastan narrative poems written by a native of
Kashghar in the nineteenth century.

Qidirkhan Yärkändi. Divan Qidiri ning muqäddimisi.
Qäshqär: Qäshqär Uyghur Näshriyati, 1986.
Transcription with translation.
The surviving parts of an introduction to a poet's
collected works, describing poetic performances in the
sixteenth century under the rule of the Yarkand
Khanate.

Yusuf Khass Hajib. Wisdom of Royal Glory (Kutadgu
Bilig); A Turko-Islamic Mirror for Princes. Robert
Dankoff, translation and notes. Chicago: University of
Chicago Press, 1983.
English translation of one of the most important early
Turkic literary works.

I am proud to announce that Antilyrik by Vitezslav Nezval, translated =
from the Czech by
Jerome Rothenberg and Milos Sovak has just been awarded the 2002 PEN =
Center USA
award for the best translation. The award committe wrote:

"The Jerome Rothenberg and Milos Sovak translation brings an essential =
voice of the European avant-garde to life in English for the first time. =
Vitezslav Nezval--poet extraordinaire, chief Czech representative of the =
playful, uniquely Czech school of Poetism in the twenties and prime =
practitioner of European-wide Surrealism in the thirties--sings and =
dances on these pages as he always has for those few who could read him =
in Czech or in the numerous fine translations into languages other than =
English...Hats off not only to the translators but also to Green =
Integer, their publishers, for recognizing the gap in our poetic culture =
and filling it with a characteristic selection of Nezval's lyric =
production."

In celebration of this award, we are offering a 20% discount to all =
people on our list. Send a check for $10.00  ($8.75 + $1.25 postage) =
made out to EL-E-PHANT at 6026 Wilshire Boulevard,
Los Angeles, CA 90036. We'll send you the book!

I would also like to mention two new Green publications:

Aphorisms by C=E9sar Vallejo, translated from the Spanish by Stephen =
Kessler
$9.95 (20% discount for people on the list and $1.25 postage)=3D$9.21

As the translator writes in his introduction: "These are not aphorisms =
in the classical sense of philosophic gemstones cut and polished to =
epigrammatic perfection. They are more like thoughts-in-progress from =
the notebooks of a radical modernism poet trying to regain his bearins =
after a consciousness-shaking encounter with Soviet socialism." In these =
short, pity, subjective statements, the great Peruvian poet, author of =
Trilce and Los heraldos negros explores his own thinking and poetics at =
an extremely important moment in his career.


Selected Poems by Else Lasker-Schuler, translated from the German by =
Audri Durchslag-Litt and Jeanette Litman-Demesstere, with a Preface by =
Yehuda Amichai.

$11.95 (20% discount plus postage of $1.25)=3D$10.81

Else Lasker-Schuler was a leading Expressionist poet and one of the =
lmost prominent women writers of the early 20th century. She has been =
described by Karl Kraus as "the greatest lyric poet of modern Germany." =
Lasker-Schuler lilved the life of a bohemian, sharing the artistic =
milieu of post World War I Berlin with friends such as Franz Marc and =
Gottfried Benn. When the Nazi government took power, Lasker-Schuler, =
after being accosted by a group of Nazis and beaten with an iron rod, =
immediately boarded a train to leave Germany. After a short stay in =
Zurich, her last years were spent in Israel, where she aligned herself =
with experimental writers celebrating their Jewish heritage.=20

Both of these books are available (with the 20% discount) from Green =
Integer, 6026 Wilshire Blvd., Los Angeles, CA 90036 .  Please write =
checks to EL-E-PHANT.

Subject:      Re: Green Integer News

>I am proud to announce that Antilyrik by Vitezslav Nezval,
>translated from the Czech by

This just in via Anglo-American friends Tony Frazer & Nathaniel Tarn:

----- Original Message -----

from the 'Books and Bookmen' column of _Private Eye_ July 26, 2002


POETS CORNERED

The small but perfectly formed world of modern British poetry looks even
smaller following the announcement of the shortlist for the Forward Prize,
Britain's biggest poetry award.

This year's judges include two poets published by Picador (Sean O'Brien and
Michael Donaghy), who have shortlisted two other Picador poets (Peter Porter
and Paul Farley) for the £10,000 top prize. Last year's judging panel also
included two Picador poets--Donaghy (again) and Peter Porter.

Last year Porter gave the main prize to Sean O'Brien. What's the betting
O'Brien won't now give it back to his mentor, enabling both friends to
pocket ten grand? Or will their protegé Paul Farley be the one to take the
loot this time around?

Last year the £5,000 prize for "best first collection" went to another
Picador poet, John Stammers (a product of Donaghy's poetry workshops), and
the £1,000 "best single poem" prize was given to Ian Duhig for a poem--you
guessed it--from his forthcoming Picador collection. The same poem earlier
won Duhig the £5,000 top prize in the Poetry Society's national poetry
competition, judged by a three-man panel including his mate Don Paterson,
the foul-mouthed Scottish bard who also happens to be the poetry editor at,
er, Picador.

This year's five-poet Forward shortlist includes two other chums, David
Harsent and John Fuller (winner of the Forward prize in 1996, when one of
the judges was again Sean O'Brien). And Sean O'Brazen was one of three
judges of the 1997 T. S. Eliot prize (worth £5,000), which was awarded to. .
. his own editor, Don Paterson.

Duhig, Donaghy, O'Brien, Harsent and Paterson all have the same agent,
TriplePa, aka Gerry Wardle--who just happens to be Sean O'Brien's partner.
And Donaghy, Duhig, Farley, Fuller, Harsent, Paterson and Porter have all
received fulsome write-ups from the _Sunday Times's_ main poetry critic, one
Sean O'Brien.

Those outside the charmed circle may wonder if there are any poets worth
honouring who don't happen to be Picador authors, friends of O'Brien or
clients of his missus. (Are there, for example, some meritorious women?
Apparently not, to judge by the omission of Alice Oswald, Carol Ann Duffy,
Helen Dunmore and Selima Hill from the Forward list.) Until the Forward
organizers desist from asking O'Brazen and his cronies to judge their prize,
we may never know.

"Bookworm"

Original Message

Sorry to be referring to something as quaint as a book, but I'm under
the impression that page numbers came about 75 years after the
appearance of books. Does anyone have a reference that goes into this
'fact'?

Best,

Ziya

_____________________________________________________

SUMMARY BELOW :
_____________________________________________________


Well, since they didn't invent the Contents Page for decades, page
numbers wouldn't have been of much use.

I have illustrations (photographic copies) of pages from various books
without any page numbers up to 1546, when a page of Hypnerotomachia
Poliphilii printed by Jacques Kerver (Paris) shows page numbers, and in
1559 Froissart's Chronicles printed at Lyons shows a page number on page
one.

You could also search for "Contents Pages, history of", since one
depends on the other.

best,

For those who aren't interested in the specifics of this, I'll just
point out the general lesson from this is that it took years to develop
the "UI" of books and other publications, but they've evolved so
successfully that they're largely "unconscious" to us (unless a
publication designer decides to alter them in ways that make them
noticeable).

Partly I'd say this is due to successful refinement after centuries of
beta testing, partly it's because this sort of UI has a lower degree of
interaction than with digital products, since the UI is more informing
your behavior, than actually providing behavior itself.

At 10:24 AM -0400 7/28/02, J.T. wrote:
>Well, since they didn't invent the Contents Page for decades, page
>numbers wouldn't have been of much use.

Actually not true. Page numbers are still useful without a contents
page.

In fact the real issue may not be page numbering per se, as much as the
fact that printing created _consistent_ page numbering across different
copies of the same book (something that didn't happen when books were
handwritten). This became a major breakthrough for intellectuals at the
time, because you could specify a reference in your book and know that
someone else who owned the same book could find it easily. It was one of
reasons behind a major shift from oral to written culture.

It's been years since my history of design class, so I don't have
specific references about this, but a 75 year lag time to create page
numbering sounds about right. <http://www.reformed.com/pub/cyber2.htm>

Walter Ong's "Orality and Literacy"
<http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0415027969/interactionby-20/102-
6903671-6524130> looked at these kinds of issues in detail, so it
probably talks about page numbering.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
----------------
George Olsen                           george@interactionbydesign.com
User Experience Architect
310-993-0467
http://www.interactionbydesign.com

_____________________________________________________


Gutenberg Bible said to be printed before 1456

Definitions from "Encyclopedia of the Book"

foliation: the forerunner of pagination; only the recto sides of leaves
in manuscripts or early printed books being numbered, usually in roman
numerals. Leaf numerals were printed as early as 1470, Johannes da Spira
of Venice being the first printer to do this.

pagination: a sequence of numbers used to identify the pages of a book.
Pagination was not in common use until the mid-16th century, prior to
which only the recto of each leaf had been numbered, i.e. foliated.

In music published during the 18th century, especially by John Walsh,
double, triple and even quadruple pagination occurs, indicating the use
in later editions of plates from former ones.

recto: 1. a bibliographer's term for the upper side of a leaf of
parchment or paper whether written or printed upon or not.  2. the
right-hand pages of a book, bearing uneven numbers.

other online info

http://www.cfpca.wayne.edu/faculty/wright/SPJ5020/02.%20Birth%20of%20a%2
0Free%20Press.html

http://lamar.colostate.edu/~hallahan/hchron.htm

http://www.speakeasy.org/~fbrown/files/lifebeing.htm

second use of the phrase "printed index" (without quotes)

_____________________________________________________


I thought the question about when paging was first added in books and
the related ideas of indexing and tables of contents was informative.
The definitions I quoted were found while researching the question.

Have a nice day
John Paul Fullerton
j-fullerton@tamu.edu

_____________________________________________________


> 75 years, even in slow times, is a pretty long time. I'm
> wondering *why* it
> would take that long to arrive at page numbering. Was it more of a
> procedural problem (binding, printing, etc) or a conceptual
> one? If the latter, why so long?

My guess is that page numbering originated to make print production
easier. I am imagining that page numbering was initially used by
printers and bookbinders to keep their pages organized - that is, to
keep the plates organized and to keep the printed papers in the correct
order before binding them. When copying texts by hand, it was probably
pretty clear which page was to be worked on next (I'm not sure, but were
the books bound before being inscribed, or after?), but in a print shop
with lots of pages and type to manage, some kind of numbering system was
probably really useful.

I wonder if page numbers migrated from being small numbered printer's
marks in the margins of the pages (where they would only be used by the
printers) onto the pages themselves, where readers and librarians and
researchers started to find them and use them?

Even today some printers and bookbinders nostalgically include
'signature marks' - a kind of "meta-" page-numbering to keep the bound
signatures (the bundles of internally-bound pages that comprise the
structure of most books) themselves in sequence. Which, if you think
about it, is silly for a book which had numbers in it! Putting
signatures in order is easy if all the pages have numbers on them!
According to this -->
<http://palimpsest.stanford.edu/don/dt/dt3111.html> signature marks
first appeared directly printed into books in 1472, which would suggest
that at that date there were still books without printed page numbers.

Anyway, perhaps this is a rare instance of where meeting the engineers'
needs ended up being really beneficial to the end user?

-Cf

[christopher eli fahey]
art: http://www.graphpaper.com
sci: http://www.askrom.com
biz: http://www.behaviordesign.com

_____________________________________________________


> 75 years, even in slow times, is a pretty long time. I'm
> wondering *why* it would take that long

Another reason: Today we use page numbers to tell other people where to
look for something in a book. Hand-copied manuscripts of the same book
were unlikely to have the same pagination. I can imagine it taking 75
years for the usefulness of page numbers became understood by readers
and scholars.

An another: A great deal of what is printed, then and now, are
broadsides, handbills, posters, and tracts - for which page numbers are
barely applicable.

-Cf

[christopher eli fahey]
art: http://www.graphpaper.com
sci: http://www.askrom.com
biz: http://www.behaviordesign.com

_____________________________________________________


> Anyway, perhaps this is a rare instance of where meeting the
engineers'
> needs ended up being really beneficial to the end user?

The thing that got me started thinking about page numbers and books is a
pet peeve that I have: streaming formats (Real, WMP, QT) are not
'bookmarkable'. I know there are some technical issues relating to
keyframes, compression and playback rates, but engineering wise it is
not impossible. I mean critics have forced even Macromedia to (sort of)
enable Flash to carry bookmarks, but for streams we still don't have an
effective bookmarking capability, without which the 'engineers' of
audio/video editing couldn't do their job at all. We had SMPTE code for
decades and web bookmarkability for almost a decade now, yet we don't
have bookmarks for audio/video streams. I sure hope it takes less than
75 years this time.

Best,

Ziya

Subject:      Mr Sondheim

A recent posting from Mr Sondheim:

I AM WHO I AM

I AM ABSOLUTION OF ALL species. EARTH, WE ARE KILLING YOU. EARTH, you are
GREEDY RAPACIOUS you are killing OCEAN. you are KILLING ALL MALIGNANT
HUMAN SPECIES OF ANY AMERIKA AND ANY PLANET. BEGONE ALL HUMAN SPECIES.
EARTH, KILL ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES. [blah... blah... ]
_________________________

With due respect, I think Mr Sondheim has it wrong on three counts here.

First, his quoting of Brahman's famous opening words ("Tat Tvam Asi"; "I am
that which I am") fails to note the curious similarity to the
famous  "Popeye Motto" ("I yam what I yam"). Lacunae as serious as these
should not go unchallenged.

Second, even teenage mail-list newcomers are expected to acknowledge the
basic etiquette of not typing their messages in capital letters.

Third, what he's "killing" with this drivel is the average well-disposed
reader's willingness to give "poetry" a hearing. (We feel we should accept
Mr Sondheim's writing as "poetry" because it is sent to a "poetry" "list",
and it doesn't appear to have any rational point to make.) Which poses a
number of questions:

Hasn't persistent self-ghettoisation run its course with Angela Davis's
failed bid for the Presidency on behalf of the Communist Party of America?

Didn't Taxi Driver (the movie) perform this particular routine more
thoroughly, profitably, and entertainingly, and that three decades ago,
already?

Where is the Ralph Nader of Poetry Marketing, to protect maimed consumers
like us?

        John Tranter

From:         Robert Corbett <rcor@U.WASHINGTON.EDU>
Subject:      Re: philosophers on poetry?
In-Reply-To:  <183.b79e795.2a6f4333@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

let's take another side of this question:  can we think of any major
analytic philosophers who _do_ write about poetry?  Searle (snicker)?
Quine?  Putnam? Singer? Rorty says things about literature--smart
things--but I do not recall him dealing with poetry.  William Gass, who
was mentioned, doesn't strike me a primarily a philosopher, though he may
be.  I do think that Stanley Cavell's thought rhymes with poetry, even if
he doesn't spend time unpacking a Robert Hass poem, but he, too, is an odd
figure in anglo-american philosophy.

readers familiar with my posts can recognize as this one as part of a
continuing series claiming that the fate of theory and the fate of
poetry--in the academy and out--have much more in common than anybody but
insiders of both communities would suspect.

Robert

Mutation 8

My place is
in a
collection of
landscape sounds,
bent windows,
piles of
junk, people
godawful contained
in the
storefront. Random
shelves group
on the
harsh curb
to implicate
capricious lines
& invisible sounds.

Dear Poetry List....

I have failed at this once before... but I thought I would try again looking
for/or to create a poetry workshop for people in Central New Jersey between
Princeton and New Brunswick.  I tried once to get a group together and then
I went away for business to Europe for three months....and the idea died,
and so I try again if there are poets who are interested in craft, who are
casual, who don't have a problem with a poet who work in a non academic
setting send me an email, and for the first three people who email me....
free beer all night on me.

Ray Bianchi

Subject:      Re: philosophers on poetry?
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.A41.4.44.0207231642090.97088-100000@dante11.u.washington.edu>

there was a wonderful piece by Cavell, around 1983, in Raritan, where he
reads Coleridge's "Ancient Mariner" in relation to Kant on the phenomenal
and noumenal (when the mariner drops "below the line" he enters the
noumenal).  Sounds bizarre, but it was actually quite persuasive.  This may
or may not be the same essay in which he talks about Emerson's "Experience"
and "Fate": I think not, but I'm not sure.

and behind Searle of course there's Austin on "parasitic not normal uses" of
speech acts--"as Walt Whitman does not seriously incite the eagle of liberty
to soar" (cf. Max Beerbohm cartoon!); and then there's the wild
Searle/Derrida exchange in Glyph, not directly about poetry though very much
about "etiolations" of language, for which in Austin's account poetry comes,
more or less, to stand.

farther back: James's Pragmatism is basically a theory of metaphor, no?  And
it values just the sort of shiftiness in model-making the metaphor in poetry
exemplifies.

sorry I'm sliding away from "Anglo-American analytic philosophers" here;
probably drifting off-topic.  I missed the opening posts of this thread . .
.

[guess i won't be featured in jacket. anyway the ref. was to ahe'eh she

the chant of trilby-svengali


i am her trilby to her svengali and she is my trilby to my svengali. i
have to create them. svengali's mental. shape-riding nobody. svengali and
trilby make perfect fuck, sharing the dream of svengali and trilby

mysterious svengali as he creates electric light to see her better

trilby to svengali's edison, dolly shot in cinerama, her trilby to her
svengali, my trilby to my svengali. she nobody. svengali and trilby make
perfect fuck, sharing

mesmeric rosy nipples entering miraculous singing long white gown falling
open from her shoulders evening primrose licking her feet drinking her
urine before the guests i will kill you but my voice must be pure tongue
within, show them who is mesmerized degradation beyond degradation
degradation beyond belief her staring is uncanny, almost as if she leaves
so quickly now, almost in a feint naked, thou hast cast me into this role
naked, i am dying of love, sweet song, mesmeric one last kiss, one last
note, one touch mesmeric songster of the night entering breathing deeply
miraculous singing hands trembling in the air evening primrose licking her
feet i will kill you but my voice must be pure tongue within, show them
who is mesmerized degradation beyond degradation degradation beyond belief
applause from an audience of thousands her staring is uncanny, almost as
if please, i can live no longer like this naked, i am dying of love, sweet
song, mesmeric one last kiss, one last note, one touch

_

----- Original Message -----

from the 'Books and Bookmen' column of _Private Eye_ July 26, 2002


POETS CORNERED

The small but perfectly formed world of modern British poetry looks even
smaller following the announcement of the shortlist for the Forward Prize,
Britain's biggest poetry award.

This year's judges include two poets published by Picador (Sean O'Brien and
Michael Donaghy), who have shortlisted two other Picador poets (Peter Porter
and Paul Farley) for the £10,000 top prize. Last year's judging panel also
included two Picador poets--Donaghy (again) and Peter Porter.

Last year Porter gave the main prize to Sean O'Brien. What's the betting
O'Brien won't now give it back to his mentor, enabling both friends to
pocket ten grand? Or will their protegé Paul Farley be the one to take the
loot this time around?

Last year the £5,000 prize for "best first collection" went to another
Picador poet, John Stammers (a product of Donaghy's poetry workshops), and
the £1,000 "best single poem" prize was given to Ian Duhig for a poem--you
guessed it--from his forthcoming Picador collection. The same poem earlier
won Duhig the £5,000 top prize in the Poetry Society's national poetry
competition, judged by a three-man panel including his mate Don Paterson,
the foul-mouthed Scottish bard who also happens to be the poetry editor at,
er, Picador.

This year's five-poet Forward shortlist includes two other chums, David
Harsent and John Fuller (winner of the Forward prize in 1996, when one of
the judges was again Sean O'Brien). And Sean O'Brazen was one of three
judges of the 1997 T. S. Eliot prize (worth £5,000), which was awarded to. .
. his own editor, Don Paterson.

Duhig, Donaghy, O'Brien, Harsent and Paterson all have the same agent,
TriplePa, aka Gerry Wardle--who just happens to be Sean O'Brien's partner.
And Donaghy, Duhig, Farley, Fuller, Harsent, Paterson and Porter have all
received fulsome write-ups from the _Sunday Times's_ main poetry critic, one
Sean O'Brien.

Those outside the charmed circle may wonder if there are any poets worth
honouring who don't happen to be Picador authors, friends of O'Brien or
clients of his missus. (Are there, for example, some meritorious women?
Apparently not, to judge by the omission of Alice Oswald, Carol Ann Duffy,
Helen Dunmore and Selima Hill from the Forward list.) Until the Forward
organizers desist from asking O'Brazen and his cronies to judge their prize,
we may never know.

"Bookworm"

I've already endorsed Alan's right to post his work on this List. I don't
enjoy watching people slam him and his work.

I wish I could say that all poets are automatically my best friends, but,
looking realistically at human nature, I can't. I choose my friends on the
basis of the integrity they display in their personal dealings with me.
While a number of my best friends are poets, I've learned over the years
that good character is not limited to people working in any one field. Good
and bad people appear in equal proportion among all professions,
ethnicities, etc. Although a common interest is always a basis for trying to
start a friendship, I've found that a shoe salesman or a physicist can be as
good as friend as a poet, jazz musician or painter.


Vernon Frazer

On Mon, 29 Jul 2002, Tenney Nathanson wrote:

> there was a wonderful piece by Cavell, around 1983, in Raritan, where he
> reads Coleridge's "Ancient Mariner" in relation to Kant on the phenomenal
> and noumenal (when the mariner drops "below the line" he enters the
> noumenal).  Sounds bizarre, but it was actually quite persuasive.  This may
> or may not be the same essay in which he talks about Emerson's "Experience"
> and "Fate": I think not, but I'm not sure.


Something I will have to look up.  There is a bizarre footnote in The
Senses of Walden, something to the effect of "Here be the
thing-in-itself," that I too found persuasive when I read it, but when I
mention it, it sounds bizarre.  It's exactly that effect that makes me say
that Cavell, of all contemporary philosophers who write in an analytic
idiom, is the only one I can think capable of writing on poetry.

>
> and behind Searle of course there's Austin on "parasitic not normal uses" of
> speech acts--"as Walt Whitman does not seriously incite the eagle of liberty
> to soar" (cf. Max Beerbohm cartoon!); and then there's the wild
> Searle/Derrida exchange in Glyph, not directly about poetry though very much
> about "etiolations" of language, for which in Austin's account poetry comes,
> more or less, to stand.
>

To me, this is not writing about poetry.  This is just illustrating speech
acts.  As I understand Searle, fictive uses are parasitic upon "real"
uses; hardly an illuminating way to read any form of literature. Austin
said things like this, but he was much funnier.

> farther back: James's Pragmatism is basically a theory of metaphor, no?  And
> it values just the sort of shiftiness in model-making the metaphor in poetry
> exemplifies.

I should have specified contemporary american philosophers, as that is
whom I meant.  I'm sure there is a Rortian version of James that makes
just such a claim, but Rorty's work is considered an aberrant form of
pragmatism by many mainline American analytic philosophers.

I have to say that as much analytic ignorance (or avoidance ) of
literature perturbs, I am almost as perturbed by moves such as Nussbaum's
and Colin McGinn's, which is to promote literature over philosophy as a
guide to life.  Their versions are not the sentimental and oversimplified
one that Oprah works with, but it nevertheless makes me a little
squirrelly.


> sorry I'm sliding away from "Anglo-American analytic philosophers" here;
> probably drifting off-topic.  I missed the opening posts of this thread . .
> .

this is a late response anyway.  but thanks for responding, as I sent this
out thinking for sure that everyone had moved on.

Robert

I'm sure there are others, but he's the one who comes to mind for me too

> >
> > and behind Searle of course there's Austin on "parasitic not
> normal uses" of
> > speech acts--"as Walt Whitman does not seriously incite the
> eagle of liberty

> > about "etiolations" of language, for which in Austin's account

> > more or less, to stand.

>
> To me, this is not writing about poetry.  This is just illustrating speech
> acts.  As I understand Searle, fictive uses are parasitic upon "real"
> uses; hardly an illuminating way to read any form of literature. Austin
> said things like this, but he was much funnier.

right, absolutely.  It's the Derrida part that's more interesting.  It's
also not very directly about poetry, but what he does (as you'd expect) is
to suggest that the supposedly peripheral stuff that Austin and then more
grimly Searle want to confine to the status of "etiolations" turns out to
inhabit the core cases as well: so that the bad stuff that "befalls" speech
acts when they turn up in poetry or other "parasitic, not normal" uses
befalls ALL speech acts, which leads to a major re-thinking of what happens
in any speech act.  and the "fictive" turns out to be central, after all.
not poetry specifically, though, in Derrida's analysis.

also worth reading: Derrida on Mallarme, I think it's in Disseminations.

>
> > farther back: James's Pragmatism is basically a theory of
> metaphor, no?  And
> > it values just the sort of shiftiness in model-making the
> metaphor in poetry
> > exemplifies.
>
> I should have specified contemporary american philosophers, as that is
> whom I meant.  I'm sure there is a Rortian version of James that makes
> just such a claim, but Rorty's work is considered an aberrant form of
> pragmatism by many mainline American analytic philosophers.
>
> I have to say that as much analytic ignorance (or avoidance ) of
> literature perturbs, I am almost as perturbed by moves such as Nussbaum's
> and Colin McGinn's, which is to promote literature over philosophy as a

> one that Oprah works with, but it nevertheless makes me a little
> squirrelly.

I don't know this stuff; sounds like I don't need to?

>

This sounds like schoolyard banter.  John Tranter's message wasn't an
attack!  geez, if Alan Sondheim can't take a critical response, even a
curmudgeonly one, why does he post 'poetry' to the list?

Anyway, I agree that

> the average well-disposed
> reader

is indeed what's at stake--a person whom today's fashionable criticism views
as a myth/nonexistant, a person increasingly alienated by illegible forms of
theory and the 'poems' that result.

I can see how it would be frustrating to not only "average readers" but
(eh-hem) well-disposed, serious editors and literary people to be constantly
subjected to a poetry that embodies the dead author, the irrelevant
audience, and the moot text. Is mechanized, compulsive, humorless,
ultra-violent ultra-pornographic faux computer jibberish all we have left?

Finally-- list etiquette? Things that are posted, by Alan Sondheim or anyone
else, imply that they should be read by list subscribers. Hence, "Skip what
you don't like," does not work as a standalone rule in communities where
people care about what others are writing, or as a defense for posts that
are wrong, objectionable, or pointless.  Should Alan Sondheim's posts only
be read/responded to by people who appreciate them as 'poetry'?   People
have to be allowed to object to something they read on this list without
smarmy "Well, I guess I won't be in JACKET, *hmph*," and "If YOU'RE SO
BORED, blah blah."

I get the feeling that this response is somehow 'part' of Alan Sondheim's
'project', but--- I'm a bit out of fashion myself, I guess.


-Bourgeois Belz

Date:         Wed, 31 Jul 2002 04:25:09 -0400

From:         Pierre Joris <joris@ALBANY.EDU>
Subject:      Re: philosophers on poetry?
In-Reply-To:  <LOBBLPJCMEPFAHHNCIBKAEEDHHAA.nathanso@u.arizona.edu>

 Tenney Nathanson wrote:

>
> also worth reading: Derrida on Mallarme, I think it's in Disseminations.
>


It is indeed worth reading -- & that book also has his excellent piece on
Philippe Sollers _Numbers_ (useful, even if the latter is called "roman") &
in _Writing and Difference_ there are good pieces on Jabès and Artaud. There
is also the anglo-gathering of Derrida texts on Lietrature, _Acts of
Literature_ (edited by Derek Attridge., Routledge).

The original question was about anglo-philosophers on poetry. I thought
about it for awhile, but couldn't come up with anybody really interesting
except the few usual suspects that had alreday be trotted out.

But -- & this may be worthwhile throwing into the fray -- what about
anglo/american poets writing (on) philosophy as/and/or poetry?  In fact, my
first reaction to Philip's question had wanted me to say: Don Byrd, _The
Poetics of the Common Knowledge_, a superb (& unhappily much neglected)
book.

Pierre
=========================================================================
Date:         Tue, 30 Jul 2002 16:39:05 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: Attacks
In-Reply-To:  <B96C5509.127FB%aaron@belz.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

subjected to a poetry that embodies the dead author, the irrelevant
audience, and the moot text. Is mechanized, compulsive, humorless,
ultra-violent ultra-pornographic faux computer jibberish all we have left?


Where is the dead author?
The audience is highly relevant; I have enough of at least a dedicated
following for it. I _care_ that the texts are read.
Moot text? The texts are pretty understandable; I know that from the more
or less constant back-channel I get.
Ultra-violent? Most of them have no violence at all. Look at the the 1000
Character Essay transformations for example.
Ultra-pornographic? - I don't find the work arousing; I doubt very many
people do. Look at the text about malignancy a few days ago - whether you
like it or not, it's political, hardly exciting.
Faux computer? No, real computer, programs, routines, commands, and heavy
editing. The programs are in perl, awk, shell script, occasionally moo
language (not recently).
Jibberish? Absolutely; I'm sure Marjorie Perloff would agree!
All we have left? I think if anything I'm in the minority here, but then
so are Mez, NN, Memmott, Solipsis, and a whole lot of other people. Look
at the o-o, arc_hive, syndicate, 7-11, and other lists.

Look at that issue of American Book Review I did a year ago with Florian
Cramer, Talan Memmott, and others in it - if anything, codework, such as
it is, is embodying a new, if not revolutionary, poetics, one based on
submerged and activated/performative structures, machinics, etc.

It seems to me that there's a double-edged dagger here - or a rolling
stone gathering no moss - or a stitch in time.

Anyway, there's a poetic avant-garde, which none of us are part of;
there's a continuous recycling of the same poetics/langpo/aesthetics/
discussions ever since I've been on Poetics at least. Not to mention the
old L*A*N*G*U*A*G*E mags which I've just been looking through. Not to
mention a huge number of current mags and probably future mags.

And then there are people embracing networking, protocols, collaborations,
performatives, inter- and intra- nets, hackings, languages (perl, shell,
awk, etc.), softwares (flash, director, etc.) - and who have been doing
this for years - and for the most part, the traditional writers are
absolutely blind to the poetics of this - for example Tranter talking
about (I think it was him) this work being churned out - it takes just as
long to write as anything else - not to mention the initial programming,
etc. etc. - if such is used -

This work is never recognized, never supported, except for a few places
such as trAce. I get republished a lot online, but not by traditional
poetry mags.

The differences are enormous. And it's as if langpo has suddenly discov-
ered some of this - look at Glazier's book - my first work along this line
was 1973, first publications in 1977...

Then there is hacker writing, the Jargon file, all of these other jargons/
dialects, things coming to the foreground. These are exciting times for
look at LANGUAGE AS A PROBLEM, not as a given to be endlessly abstracted
and brought back a la langpo. What happens w/ a program that must be
EXACTLY written to function as desired, against or interspersed with
natural language? Just look at the history of google.com!

Then there's Andy Oram's recent talk on the intensive textuality of
regular expressions - in other words, their poetics - in relation to
McLuhan's problematizing of electronic media and the dispersal of the
Word. ...

Anway, I care obviously if people hate the stuff - and for them it is
_stuff,_ - but the problem is that this is accompanied in so many ways by
ignorance of the issues, no matter how many times I/we try to clarify
them.

Alan

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Aaron Belz <aaron@BELZ.NET>
Subject:      Re: Attacks
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.NEB.4.44.0207301620310.7149-100000@panix3.panix.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

> And then there are people embracing networking, protocols, collaborations,
> performatives, inter- and intra- nets, hackings, languages (perl, shell,
> awk, etc.), softwares (flash, director, etc.) - and who have been doing
> this for years - and for the most part, the traditional writers are
> absolutely blind to the poetics of this

> Anway, I care obviously if people hate the stuff - and for them it is
> _stuff,_ - but the problem is that this is accompanied in so many ways by
> ignorance of the issues, no matter how many times I/we try to clarify
> them.


Alan,

I am glad you care about this 'stuff', and thank you for the informative
post about your process. In fact I do come from a digital media background
and am not ignorant of computer culture and the soft and hard tools people
use to create and organize information, how networks work, etc. I am also
aware that there are a number of misguided attempts to make "art! art!"
where there is no art (not speaking of you, Alan, but of others), especially
in the information/communications technology world. Hopefully a given work
of art won't be condemned *or* defended solely on its process or the
theoretical "issues" that lie behind it.

Viable process does equal viable product.  For instance, I have a hard time
appreciating "BEGONE ALL HUMAN SPECIES. Understand this BEGONE ALL HUMAN
SPECIES ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES. EARTH, KILL ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES
ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES OF ANY AMERIKA AND ANY PLANET. BEGONE ALL HUMAN
SPECIES. KILL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES. EARTH,
KILL ALL MALIGNANT HUMAN SPECIES."  That seems doltish to me, unreflective,
ill-considered.  Or this: "missing stromatolite the pictures are coming
perfectly along. i've been inntrol, youcan bet i've ben in control, hehh heh
heh not like now but geere or gettingewhre, the packets are ipping from me"
I mean, what's the point of reading this? What am I supposed to be getting
from that?  I guess I have to respect your process, which strikes me as a
kind of Jackson-Pollack-does-computer-poetry. The result of that process is
what I reserve the right to express frustration with.  By comparison,
jodi.org is much more interesting & addresses "the issues" much more
eloquently.

My main point anyway -- and perhaps the one I should have stuck with-- is
that it should not be out-of-bounds to express frustration with your poetry
on this list or any other that you post it to.  That's part of the game,
right?

Without bitterness,
Aaron

This 360-page double issue brings together more than 50 German-
language writers, particularly those who have emerged since 1989 and
those not well-represented in English translation.

Literature". Ha! Anyway, enough of a plug for a journal I like.
